Regarding the prospect of Alawite defections from Assad's regime, there's this: http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/features/2016/03/18/Syria-s-Alawites-bear-brunt-of-Assad-after-soaring-death-toll-.html This is from a Sunni Arab source that probably sympathizes more with the rebels than the regime. But two things are noteworthy: first, the Alawite dissident movement is headquartered in Turkey, and according to its founder Fouad Hamira, "...the Alawites currently serving in opposition groups were mostly “communists or secularists.” He wishes to herald yet another revival - an opposition group based on a solid Alawite identity - apart from Assad." So there's an existing opposition, this is just an attempt to create an alternative opposition. It may have a better chance of succeeding than the secularists have, but that remains to be seen. But here's the real problem: "But Hamira believes that not only Alawites must strike a more reconciliatory chord. Some of the numerous opposition groups must “tone down their sectarian diatribe,” he said." If the Alawites don't believe that the Sunnis will be conciliatory, they will stick with Assad no matter how dissatisfied they are. The Yazidis were a marginalized group without any political power, and were massacred and enslaved. The Alawites are a minority, hated for their abuses while in power, and have given the Sunnis ample reasons to engage in reprisals when the time comes. The Alawites have no choice but to fight or to negotiate a partition of Syria that gives them independence or at least a level of autonomy that makes them effectively sovereign in their own territory. They have too much at stake to rely on the promises and good faith of their enemies. There is no second chance if a group's strategy of conciliation turns out to be wrong or if the other side reneges on promises to forswear retaliation. Somewhat related is this: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2016/03/16/putin-cant-last-forever-will-a-post-putin-russia-look-like-syria-today/ Interestingly, this article is dated two days before the al-Arabiya article and gives pretty much exactly the opposite picture of the Alawites. But the article itself is about the tenuousness of Putin's hold on power in Russia. This is why I consider any prospect of Assad "retiring" to Russia to be impractical. Under the current international law regime, there would be absolutely no way to immunize Assad (or anyone else) from prosecution for war crimes. Even if some state were to give him asylum, the charges against him would stand; the charges would not be voided simply because trying Assad was impractical or even impossible. Any post-Putin regime, no matter what its political orientation, could gain international prestige by handing over Assad to the ICC or some other tribunal. This action would be virtually cost-free for the new Russian regime, and its political payoff would easily be greater than the benefit of letting Assad stay on in Moscow, or Sochi, or wherever. Assad knows this, and realizes that he has only three alternatives: in power, in prison, or dead. He will never take a "deal;" there is no deal anyone can make that offers him safety.

It is tempting to substitute this question with “Will the international community reach an agreement in which Bashar al-Assad ceases to be President of Syria before March 1, 2017?” However, doing so is a mistake, because it only makes a negotiated settlement the only possibility of Assad leaving office. The word “cease” is important, because there are multiple possibilities for Assad to vacate his position. For example, he could die, but that is a long shot. There are no reports of Assad suffering any health issues or preexisting medical conditions, and he is only 49 years old. This makes the likelihood of natural death unlikely. (Kudos to Aches for raising this possibility, hadn't considered it.) Despite the assassination of several generals throughout the civil war, there are no reports of problems with Assad's personal security. A successful assassination attempt is doubtful, with only one mediocre attempt reported from a major news outlet (http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidesyria/2013/08/201381181226943357.html) in August 2013. An internal coup is also unlikely, as the majority of top government personnel are Alawite and linked to the Assad family, making them fairly loyal. Assad could flee the country and thus cease to be President of Syria, but this too is unlikely. The recent reversal of fortune on the battlefield and reports of the US accepting Assad as the President of Syria for at least another year (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/us-sees-assad-staying-power-until-least-march-2017-report-23413683) leave Assad is a strong position with no real reason to leave Syria. If he left now with no guarantees for diplomatic protection under a deal, he could face prosecution for war crimes in the future. With the death and cowardice unlikely to change the course of the Syrian civil war, a negotiated settlement is the only real reason Assad would cease to be President of Syria. So what are the odds of diplomatic talks sending Assad packing? Not good. Two sources (http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/24/weekinreview/24bowley.html and https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/10/23/political-science-says-syrias-civil-war-will-probably-last-at-least-another-decade/) suggest an end to the current conflict in Syria is unlikely. The average civil war last around 10 years, meaning a conclusion to the conflict in Syria is improbable. The chances of the Syria becoming an outlier of that average are slim as it meets several conditions for prolonged fighting, including intervention by foreign powers and a multitude of factions in the fray. The odds of a negotiated settlement are even worse than an end to the fighting. According to a similar source (http://politicalviolenceataglance.org/2013/10/18/the-four-things-we-know-about-how-civil-wars-end-and-what-this-tells-us-about-syria/) the chance of a negotiated settlement in any civil war is around 25%. That chance depends on two factors, explained in the source, that have a lower probability of occurring, undermining the chance even further of a negotiated settlement. The odds of the rebels military defeating Assad are also considerably low. Rebels have a 35% average of a decisive military victory in a civil war. But Syrian rebels forces are fighting Assad, PYG Kurds, ISIS/Daesh, Shiite militias, Hezbollah, and amongst themselves. Their stronghold of Aleppo is close to encirclement, which threatens supplies necessary to sustain armed opposition. Supported by Russia and Iran, the Syrian Army is unlikely to face a similar strain on resources. The West and its Gulf allies are focused primarily on combating terrorism, not ousting Assad from power, leaving the rebels to fend for themselves.  In summary:
Assad is likely to survive until March 1, 2017. The chances of a successful assassination attempt or an internal coup are low. (+ 3%)
He is unlikely to flee the country. (+3%)
The odds of a negotiated settlement before March 1, 2017 are quite low, and those odds decrease when you consider how much the question of Assad leaving offices slows or even stalls diplomatic talks. Even if negotiations are successful, the chances of removing Assad from power before March 1, 2017 are low. (25% base for negotiated settlements, subtract 15% for lack of factors that lead to successful negotiations, subtract 5% for declining support of “Assad Must Go” in diplomatic talks: +5%)
The probability of a military victory over the Syrian Army by the rebels is also quite low. (35% base rate but when considering average length of civil wars, relative strength of rebel enemies, recent battlefield setbacks, etc. I think dropping it to +5% is generous.)  I conclude there is a 16% chance of Assad ceasing to be President of Syria by March 1, 2017. **** UPDATE: Lowering due to new Iranian "Red Line" - 11%

But we both know that more needs to be done in terms of both a reduction of violence and the flow of humanitarian aid.” There is of course much more to be done, and if the cessation of hostilities continues to hold and expand, it will be the result of a deep and impactful partnership between Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov. Kerry said March 24 that the United States and Russia have agreed to press for expanded humanitarian assistance, the release of detainees and an acceleration of the political process leading to a transition government, a new constitution and elections. The same day, UN Special Envoy for Syria Staffan de Mistura said that both the Syrian government and the opposition delegations had taken the first round of negotiations “very seriously.” Talks are expected to resume in April. The latest on the Geneva talks: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/24/syria-peace-staffan-de-mistura-talks-un-envoy-statement-principles Here's a salient quote: "The terrorist attacks in Brussels again underlined the centrality of the talks to Europe’s security, and even led the EU foreign representative, Federica Mogherini, to make a surprise visit to Geneva on Thursday to urge both sides not to play games, but to negotiate and reach a settlement that creates a united front to attack Islamic State (Isis)." It's been pretty clear since the end of last year that Putin is hedging his bets. He wants to cobble together some kind of alliance between the regime and selected rebel militias. Given the quote above, it looks like the EU is, for its own reasons, on board with a similar idea. I would imagine that since his objective is to secure Russian bases on the coast, what he wants from the rebels is some kind of guarantee that they will acquiesce to a permanent Russian presence in Syria if they win, or in some way find themselves in power. This means two things: 1) Assad will do everything he can to prevent any kind of understanding between Putin and any large coalition of rebel factions, and 2) Assad is safe as long as there is no accommodation between the rebels and Putin.  So I expect the talks to drag on, with the regime saying enough to keep them going while it attempts to retake whatever it can from al-Nusra and ISIS, but not making any concessions. Assad's greatest advantage is that he is no longer the worst bad guy in Syria.

http://tass.ru/en/world/864368 Dateline 3-24-16 Two North Korean militia units are fighting in Syria in support of Bashar Al-Assad’s government in that country’s civil war, Russian news agency TASS reported Tuesday. Asaad Al-Zoubi, head delegate of the High Negotiations Committee (HNC) of the Syrian opposition, reported the presence of North Korean militia units in Syria while attending peace talks at the United Nations European headquarters in Geneva. According to Al-Zoubi, the two units are known as “Cholma-1” and “Cholma-7” (written as Chalma by some sources). The name Cholma means “iron horse” in Korean. The opposition forces fighting the Al-Assad regime consider the presence of foreign troops supporting Al-Assad to be a serious threat. “North Korean troops are fatally dangerous,” Al-Zoubi explained. The report has not been yet verified by any other source. The years of continual warfare in Syria have made it increasingly difficult to accurately confirm or refute such presences and activity within the country. If true, such operations could constitute a violation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 1874 – adopted in 2009 – and UNSC Resolution 2270 – adopted earlier this month. Paragraph 9 of Resolution 2270 prohibits “the procurement from the DPRK of technical training, advice, services or assistance related to the provision, manufacture, maintenance or use of arms and related materiel.”  https://www.nknews.org/2016/03/n-korean-militia-units-fighting-in-syria-opposition-delegate/

I believe that Bashar al-Assad will not cease to be president of Syria before this date due to a number of different factors. For one, Syria is going through a major crisis with ISIS inhabiting a good chunk of the country. The International community cannot balance two conflicts in one country, and they are focusing on ISIS due to their crimes against humanity. It is fairly unlikely that this conflict will be resolved before that time. In addition, even if it was, Russia still provides Assad with weapons, which would give him some power.

He will likely remain in office because he has extreme control over a big portion of the Syrian government. He has noted that he would stay in office until terrorism has been eradicated, which doesn't seem likely by March 1, 2017 as ISIS continues to wreak havoc in the middle east.

A large factor in this is who the next president is. Until then, Obama is unlikely to take drastic steps to topple Al-Assad. If it were Donald Trump, who is planning to go along with Putin and mostly embrace isolationism, it is unlikely that al-Assad would be overthrown. However, other GOP candidates along with Hillary Clinton may favor more aggressive policies; however, it is unlikely that much would happen in so little time.

Due to a civil war in Syria and due to the lack of support for Bashar al-Assad by many of the world’s powers.  Russia, even though they are still supporting him militarily, said they are opposed to him and the United States are opposed.  With the support of the Russian military and the inability of the Syrian people to overthrow him, a change would have to occur from the United States or some other world power besides Russia.  I do not see that occurring unless al-Assad creates a truly heinous crime which I see as a possibility.

My prediction: 35%
Since al-Assad will step down because if the Civil war in Syria ends before March 2017 it will be very likely that he ceases to be president, but there is still a chance he will stay in presidency, and there is no guarantee that the war will end that soon. Also, there is a very small chance he would be killed in office because of the sheer amount of defense he has.

Upon reflection, I think that Assad's position has actually been improved at this point.  Russian support has degraded so-called moderate opposition, and cleared the field for ISIS and Nusra Front.  This has shaped the choice for Syria's future and made it much more difficult for any party attached to the position that "Assad must go."  If you could wave a magic wand and make Assad disappear today, essentially you would be surrendering the country to ISIS and Nusra Front.  Who would welcome that?  Putin has played a skillful game.  He has changed the situation on the ground to strengthen Assad's position.  Moreover, the Russians aren't really leaving anyway.  Go ahead.  Hold all the peace talks you want.  No one's going to agree to trade Assad for ISIS and Nusra Front.  Sorry about that.

- The chances of a dictator being ousted by a rebel force is low. 
- Rebels in Syria have been weakened by Assad, Putin, and Isis. 
- Assad is a strategic advantage for Isis because he keeps the US from getting a foothold in the upper levels of government in the region where Assad still controls. 
- Assad comes from a family with a history of violence and ruthlessness in the quest for maintaining control. 
- Nobody inside of the Assad regime has the recognition or credibility to govern, so an internal coup is very unlikely (less than 1-2%). 
- Assad has held on for 5 years of war. In other words, Assad has faced mortal threat for years but still holds on, albeit to a smaller stretch of land.

Assad seems to be in a reasonable position.  Despite the announced withdrawal of (some) Russian forces from Syria he is still being backed by Putin.  His regime is on a far more robust footing than six months ago, and a great deal would have to happen to see him fall from power.  It is worth considering the different plausible futures that might lead to Assad NOT being President on 1 March 2017, their likelihood and from there come up with a forecast of the chance of him staying in power.
I currently envision five scenarios (with the assumption Assad wants to remain President):
Accidental death or other severe impairment/illness that leads to his removal - remote (1%)
Internal coup / assassination - highly unlikely (4%)
Opposition / Daesh assassination of Assad - highly unlikely (10%)
Forced from power by Russia and/or Iran to facilitate a peace agreement in Syria - unlikely (15%) in the time frame
Still President on 1 March 2017 - likely (70%)

A couple of interesting things in this article: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-19/assad-foes-seek-purge-of-security-officials-in-proposal-to-un First, an inadvertently amusing remark from a spokesman for the rebel HNC: "Assad’s delegation is still “not serious” about the negotiations, al-Muslet said." The rebels are demanding that Assad step down after he has fought the rebel coalition to a standstill. There is no reason that Assad should consider this proposal to be "serious." That demand is not even viable as an initial negotiating position; there is every reason to expect Assad to reject it out of hand.  But this is more important: "The HNC is prepared to hold talks with Russian officials about Syria, al-Muslet said. Russia’s military intervention last year turned the tide of the civil war in Assad’s favor. The nation has said it’s pursuing strikes against Islamic State and the al-Qaeda linked Nusra Front." And later in the article: "The HNC supports keeping government institutions intact, al-Muslet said. “But when it comes to security and military, there has to be a restructuring.” Opposition forces would also seek to unite with Syrian government troops to fight Islamic State during the transitional phase, he said. “We insist on doing it because we don’t want to see terrorism, not in Syria or in any other country,” he said." So the rebels are willing to talk to the Russians, want to carry on the war against ISIS and al-Nusra in alliance with some kind of regime armed forces, and appear to be adopting the Russian language about "fighting terrorism." It looks like the rebels may be interpreting the withdrawal (such as it is) as an opening deal with the Russians, and if they can negotiate with Putin independently, they may be able to cut some kind of deal where Russia's strategic interest is confirmed by a new regime, and Russia agrees to try to ease Assad out. I still don't think Putin has that kind of power, but the rebels may think he does. I'm sure Putin would be happy to hedge his bets by opening channels to the rebels.

Putin's decision for a partial pullout means that Russia's putative ability to "replace" Assad is thinner than ever. The idea that Moscow had the ability to get rid of Assad was not terribly realistic anyway, but for the moment Russia's leverage is markedly decreased. I consider it unlikely that the rebels will be able to restore the position they held six months ago any time soon, so I doubt if Assad is in any immediate danger from the rebels. Now the danger to him is that Russia's absence will tempt Turkey will intervene militarily, and that Saudi Arabia will step up efforts to improve the rebels' military position. This might induce Iran to return to being Assad's primary patron, but maybe not. Moreover, the manpower shortages that plagued the regime last fall will no longer be offset by Russian air power. I think the ceasefire will hold for now, and that the negotiations will continue. I also think that there is no one on the horizon to replace Assad, so that as long as he can keep people talking he's safe, regardless of the removal of Russian military support. If the ceasefire does not hold, Iran will re-intervene, and perhaps Russia will redeploy some assets. So for now, anyway, Assad is safe.

"Russia intervened in Syria for several reasons. Its stated goal was to fight the Islamic State and other militant groups to which many Russian nationals (and other former Soviet nationals) belong. Although Russia ended up concentrating the bulk of its attention on rebels fighting the Syrian regime rather than on Islamic State fighters, there is no denying that Russia has indeed contributed to the serious damage inflicted on Islamist militants over the past months. "Haunted by past failures of intervention, Russia also wanted to demonstrate to the world — particularly to the United States — that it could successfully assert itself militarily and politically beyond its borderlands. The Kremlin wanted to have its voice heard. In the weeks after Russia first intervened in Syria, U.S. President Barack Obama downplayed Russia's actions, saying that Moscow acted out of weakness. In the months since, Russia (along with Iran) has stabilized and bolstered the Syrian regime and the forces loyal to it. In addition, its involvement in Syria, limited though it was, has given Russia the opportunity to brandish its refitted military, demonstrating its recovery from post-Soviet decay. "Russia is not completely abandoning Syria with the drawdown. Although Moscow has indicated that its main air grouping will be withdrawn, it has given no firm withdrawal end date and has made it clear it will keep the Bassel al Assad air base near Latakia and the naval base at the port of Tartus" - Stratfor, 15MAR16

Setting up a transitional government will not be easy, given the various factions and the differing starting positions regarding Assad:
----Saudi Arabia: either Assad leaves as a result of a political process or the war will continue
----Syrian Opposition: Assad must leave at the start of the transition
----The West (US): Assad should leave at some point, but not resulting in the further destabilization of Syria
----Russia: The Syrians must decide their own future
----Assad: the process must be constitutional (constitution does not provide for transitional governments)

This article mentions the Saudi jets in Turkey, but makes no mention of Saudi ground troops. That doesn't mean they aren't there, but probably not in significant numbers. My guess is special forces. http://www.reuters.com/article/mideast-crisis-syria-idUSKCN0VN03B That the Assad regime feels confident enough to announce a move against Raqqa once it takes Aleppo is noteworthy. And perhaps the most noteworthy quote is this one: "The U.S. government said Assad was "deluded" if he thought there was a military solution to the conflict." If Assad succeeds in regaining control of all Syria, it will change the popular perspective on great-power intervention in their clients' wars. Right now, the model is Vietnam. From this, people around the world (and especially the U.S.) extrapolate that great power intervention is always a failure, and may even be counterproductive to the great power's intentions. If Syria is reconstituted as a result of Russian intervention, the assumption about the efficacy of intervention will change. Russia is completely indifferent to condemnation, and is single-minded in pursuing its goal. The lesson is that if a great power intervenes and is willing to shrug off world opinion and do what it thinks it must, it will succeed. I'm not sure that the Syria intervention can actually be considered an example applicable elsewhere, but I don't think there was any reason to think that Vietnam was universally applicable either. Nevertheless, the Vietnam intervention was widely seen to provide such a "lesson."  How many times since September have we heard warnings of a Russian "quagmire" in Syria?  There are a couple of  qualifications I have to make. First, the Balkan air campaigns of the 1990s succeeded. NATO's goals were met in both Bosnia and Kosovo. But the goal was limited; it was to force a negotiated settlement. Syria is different. The goal there is the active conquest (or reconquest) of territory held by the enemy. The closest thing I can think of since 1945 is the Indian intervention to secure the independence of Bangladesh in 1971. But that was a quick blitzkrieg that produced a fait accompli. It wasn't a gradual systematic series of operations as Syria is. Syria may show that a great power can engage in a war involving multiple continuing operations,  and succeed. The second qualification is that the Syrian war is not over yet. The regime's success may be reversed, and Russia may yet face a long slog. But if the effort succeeds, the idea that conflicts have "no military solution" will no longer be taken as given.
With the passage of time, and with Assad winning the war (thanks to his Russian and Iranian partners) it seems more likely that he stays.

The predictions of the end of al-Assad have been commonplace since the first protests. The most pointed occured in July of 2012 after a group of military officers defected to form the Free Syrian Army (http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2077348,00.html). During the ripples of this defection, the al-Assad family fled to the Alawite North-West of Syria, leading to even greater speculation that his end was near.(http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/9412126/Syria-Bashar-al-Assad-flees-to-Latakia.html) That was nearly four years ago. Why is al-Assad still in power? The history of Syria: the way in which it was administered by landed elite under the Ottomans, followed by the chaotic years following French mandate, Hafez al-Assad's essentially plebian revolution and later slide back towards a system of landed elite; all of this plays a role in the current situation. Al-Assad is seen by those with purses and guns as the only game in town, what's more, he's the only one with a real bureaucracy in place to handle the duties of a state. While the main pillars of that bureaucracy have fallen, the violence pillar remains. This is not a functional state by any means, but it is much better than any can offer.  Further, the question itself misunderstands how deep the problem of unseating al-Assad is: forcing him from Damascus and into hiding didn't mean the end in 2012 and it wouldn't in 2016. The defection of military officers certainly scared the regime and forced his family to retreat temporarily, but they were ultimately able to weather the storm and return. Even after military successes, there is no force (outside of, perhaps, ISIS) with an organizational structure that would allow them to run a replacement state. Thus, even if they become more powerful militarily, they would be unable to govern and al-Assad forces would fight from strongholds claiming legitimacy and waiting for the dominant rebel group to fall apart. Samer Aboud does an excellent job at discussing how the regime arrived at its monopoly on organization (http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/23444/syria_an-interview-with-samer-abboud), though he's forced to leave out a great amount of detail. When I started, I selected 5%, but even leaving 2% seems generous, both Iran and Russia appear to be in a dollar auction situation supporting al-Assad (http://www.mediate.com/articles/noll1.cfm). Further, there's no one waiting in the wings to replace him as the head of a new Syria. Manaf Tlass was suggested some time ago, but has disappeared since 2013.

Assad could basically leave power in these ways:
- ISIS conquering Syria. Practically impossible; they got their nose bloodied by the Kurds already, and won't stand much of a chance fighting an offensive campaign against an organized army. <5%
- NATO powers deposing Assad. Possible, but unlikely before ISIS is defeated or at least pushed out of Syria, which may well take longer than a year. Until then, Assad is a useful tyrant, and western states almost never topple those. ~20%
- A successful revolution in Syria by one of the other players in the civil war. Very unlikely without foreign support (which itself is very unlikely before ISIS is defeated, and somewhat unlikely even after); on their own, they didn't even come close until now. Plus, as long as ISIS is at large, nobody will show much interest in Assad's human rights violations, giving him more options to crack down on internal opposition. ~5%
- Accident, assassination, health reasons, etc. Does happen, but very rarely. <5%

I'm just playing around with this question by modifying the % slightly. I think it is more of an excuse to think aloud about it. At the end of the day, I can't see how Assad survives. Now, whether that will take a year or four, is anybody's guess (knowing a superforecaster might help -lol). There are a couple primary differences between his reign and his father's. While his father had to engage in a similar uprising/war, he had the benefit of a somewhat controlled country (I say that loosely) whereas the current Assad faces a completely fractured country with major internationally supported "rebels". The second difference....is simply the era we are in. Everybody can communicate with almost anybody almost instantaneously, so recruitment and lifeline stories are all about us. The exodus of the current situation goes on and on putting huge pressures among many countries. [It should be clear by now....PANDORA IS OUT.} While it seems, on the face right now, that Russia and Iran are in the same camp, I think it is more of the-enemy-of-my-enemy is my friend. Nor does it seem that Russia's and Iran's long term mutual interests necessarily coincide. Russia wants the Naval facilities and a stable government. This is their bottom line. But Iran seems to be pursuing a Shia theological perspective; and a stable government as well.  From a public perspective, this entire question will remain opaque. Neither Russia nor Iran will be very public announcing a position to remove Assad and family. It will be .....we're behind you 100% (but not really). Over time, the costs and political risk of proximity chaos will probably, finally, drive Russia and Iran to move forward.  As far as the US and its allies?......I can only see a path that somehow facilitates handoff of the Assad regime to a set of Syrian generals that can moderate the Russia-Iran tensions, even if they are not ones we would prefer. Maybe it is ok just to have a stable region regardless of whether it is a white hat or black hat in control. There is always another time and another place. Will this happen by March 2017 (It's all opaque so something may be moving in backrooms), but since it's not apparent and sides seem to be digging in, I'm lowering % slightly. [...]
2) Can't keep the Assad regime but can't get rid of it either It's not that Assad is himself so crucially important. But he is at the middle of a fundamental disagreement over Syria's future, one to which there is, as yet, no clear middle ground. The question of whether he stays or goes has become a question about the degree to which Syria does or doesn't return to the prewar status quo, and right now the major parties of this war just can't agree on that. Syria's opposition, after years of enduring Assad's barrel bombs and chemical weapons, and the forced disappearances and torture chambers before them, have said over and over they could never accept that Assad stay in office. But it's not just that rebel leaders won't accept it; Assad has so completely alienated the country's Sunni majority that his very ability to govern the country, in peace or war, may well be gone. His policies are such a driver of sectarianism that he makes the country ungovernable, and peace is simply impossible while he remains in office. So when people say that Assad has lost legitimacy and has to go, that's not an opinion but rather an analytical fact about Syria. At the same time, Russia and especially Iran, whether we like it or not, are so involved in the conflict that they have effective veto power. And they see the Assad regime as essential for preserving their interests in Syria, and have demonstrated they're willing to accept significant losses to keep him in power. There are hints that those countries might be willing to push out Assad, but both would almost certainly want to replace him with another Alawite, thus keeping the regime basically the same. And it's not even clear that Russia or Iran can push out Assad. Moscow reportedly tried to remove him in December and failed. The Syrian regime still stands behind Assad, and Russia ultimately can't tell them what to do. The fact that Assad can play Russia and Iran off one another — there have been reports of long-running tension between them over Syria — makes it easier for him to stand up to them. The only other obvious option, supporting rebels until they can topple Assad by force, would invite a disaster potentially even worse than we have now. Syrians are already suffering mass displacement and, with state services in many places nonexistent, face extreme poverty, disease outbreaks, and hunger. They cannot endure the collapse of what little of the state remains. In the majority of the country where Assad has lost control, territory is divided among many different rebel groups. Were Assad to fall, they would lose their common enemy and could turn on one another. In such conditions, ISIS would almost certainly come out ahead. Many warn that should Syria's government collapse, it would follow Libya's path to chaos and infighting. But this may actually understate the problem. It's more likely, perhaps, that Syria would look like Afghanistan in the 1990s, when the collapse of the pro-Soviet government led to years of civil war among rebel groups, many of whom became more like warlords, and provided the conditions for the rise of the Taliban. ~~~~ COMMENT: Sort of seems like the international community is stuck between a rock and a hard place, but that's obviously a fluid assessment.

I cross-posted this story at the Syrian elections thread. http://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2016-01-29/syrian-opposition-not-in-geneva-on-the-day-of-peace-talks I think this is a telling exchange. (The HNC is the rebel negotiating team): "A Western diplomat in close contact with the SNC said in Geneva that "their (HNC) main message to us has been while we are under sustained attack by Russia and the regime and other states and militants and other groups we cannot justify to Syrians why we are going." "We tell them the reason to come here is not to hand the Assad regime a propaganda victory," said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak on behalf of the opposition." Another typical western flight from reality. The factions in Syria are not interested in propaganda victories. They are interested in battlefield victories. There have been several regime victories in succession recently, and no rebel victories to speak of (except ISIS gains). The rebels are going into the talks from a position of weakness, so they understandably feel that it's best to not even begin. For the rebels to negotiate under these circumstances could be interpreted as a prelude to surrender.  I'm waiting for some western diplomat to start talking about the "moral high ground." Right now, Assad's army is taking the topographical high ground in northern Latakia. Once that's secure, the Latakia redoubt will be close to impregnable; the rebels would be unable to even attack it without catastrophic losses. And the odds of any such attack succeeding would be nil. But we have western diplomats talking about perceptions. Events on the ground are shaping the future of Syria, and everyone with an actual stake in the war knows it.

On 22 January 2016, Financial Times, citing anonymous "senior western intelligence officials", claimed that Russian general Igor Sergun, the director of GRU, the Main Intelligence Directorate of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation, had shortly before his sudden death on 3 January 2016 been sent to Damascus with a message from Vladimir Putin asking that president Bashar Assad step aside. Assad was said to have "angrily refused", Sergun’s failed mission in Damascus leaving Assad "more entrenched than before". The newspaper′s report was promptly denied by Putin′s spokesman. The State Department said on Wednesday [6-January] a timeline was prepared late last year as a guide for John Kerry, Secretary of State, and other American diplomats as they worked on a political transition for Syria. John Kirby, a spokesman, described the document as a "staff-level think piece" that is "preliminary and pre-decisional" and not "an official position." However, the document reflects details of a plan negotiated in Vienna in November for a ceasefire followed by a new constitution and a transitional government. Elections for a president and new government would eventually come in August 2017. The timeline indicates that the earliest Assad would step down would be March 2017. 27-Jan-2016: Rebel negotiators said that US Secretary of State John Kerry had told them they might have to accept­ Bashar al-Assad as part of a future Syrian government of ­national unity. That would mark a significant change in the US position. It has insisted Assad had to stand down while a transition administration ran the country before elections. A unity government could allow him to stand for re-election, with no set timetable for his departure. Putin can't get rid of Assad. Here's the most important quote from the Financial Times story: "However, Russia overplayed its hand, the official said, and Mr Assad made clear to Sergun that there could be no future for Russia in Syria unless he remained as president." So Putin may have tried to talk Assad out of office, but he failed. And here's the second most important quote, which should be news to no one: "In his dealings with the Kremlin, Mr Assad has adopted a strategy of playing one foreign power off against another. His trump card on this occasion was Iran. Russia has been nervous of Tehran’s growing regional influence at the cost of its own leverage for months." Assad actually has a fairly good bargaining position: he's the only person who can actually deliver to the Russians what they want, and he can always cozy up to one sponsor if the other gets too demanding. As for the Russians, they're stuck with him. Now that they have made this commitment, any withdrawal will be a humiliating admission of failure. The Russians are stuck with Assad, and stuck in Syria. They are supporting him because having committed themselves to intervention in Syria, they are left with no choice. And Assad will insure that no choice presents itself in the future. To clarify my own thinking a review of how one can "cease to be President" is useful: 1. He's dead. Not likely with Russia protecting him. ~2% 2. He quits (probably to leave for Russia). I used to think this might happen soon, perhaps even at Russia's request, but I don't think they have anyone else in mind, and I think the west has such a terrible bargaining position ("Please make it stop.") that they are unlikely to stand on this as a firm negotiating position. ~10% 3. He loses an "election". This is the most likely way that he goes, but the question is when. The 18-month transition period is the only thing that's been floated, and negotiations don't seem to be going anywhere right now. Nor are they likely to anytime soon, with Iran and SA at each other's throats. I'd put the probability of this occurring prior to March 1, 2017 at 10%. In short, the U.S. wants a deal, but they have no leverage and they're busy dealing with SA. They'll try hard to get something before Obama leaves office to avoid a "stain on his legacy", but that's a little ways off yet, and even then they'll probably settle for anything that they can call a resolution with a straight face. Russia doesn't want to be there forever (it's expensive and invites terrorist attacks at home and abroad), but another 6 months is probably acceptable. So I think that we'll see a deal in late summer or fall, and it will include a transition period that is at least 12 months, if not 18.  I'll stick to my 22% guesstimated above out of pure intellectual honesty, though I'm tempted to apply a seat-of-the-pants pessimism downgrade to 15% or less. But we're all on here to learn how to do things by the seat of pants less often, aren't we?

As an early proponent of the use of seige-tactics, I have a question for any and all practitioners of "lawfare." Let's say, for arguments sake, we grant that intentional starvation of civilians is not a good thing. What would be the case if, rather than having the burden fall upon those conducting the siege to deliver food, the burden was placed upon those forces occupying the city to allow any and all "hungry" civilians to flee under promise of safe conduct and protection? There's food available for the citizens. They only need to leave the city to obtain it. If the occupying force does not allow them to leave, upon whose shoulders should the accusation of war crimes be placed? No one is for killing innocent civilians. I'm just thinking there is possibly a misplaced  "presumption" in this apparently generally-accepted argument.

A pretty good op-ed on the matter of Assad getting asylum in Russia: http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/13/exiling-assad-russia-syria One sentence, in my opinion, sums up Putin's stance on the idea: "Putin has always been adept at the political stall, not ruling any proposal tossed to him in or out, and his answer here – it was “premature” to discuss the issue – conforms to that pattern." To my knowledge, Putin has never categorically ruled out any scenario mooted by the west, whether it came through official sources or the press. The only things he has said he rules out completely are negotiations with ISIS and al-Nusra, which the west also rules out. Since Putin has indicated that he will entertain anything that is suggested, it's impossible to divine what outcome he would really support in the end. Putin wants to position himself as the most reasonable guy in the mix; he supports Assad, but not unconditionally, he also arms (he says) selected rebel groups; he's semi-allied to Iran, but takes no action when Israel bombs Hezbollah positions; he contributes to international efforts to end the war, and votes with the other members of the Security Council to call for a ceasefire and talks.  He will essentially give a conditional "yes" to any question anybody asks him. His statements are just diplomatic technique; none of them really commits him to anything. Here's my reading of Putin's mind: If in the end it turns out that he doesn't want to support something, he can say, "Well, I didn't dismiss the idea, but I was never definitely in favor of it." If in the end he agrees to something that was suggested, he can say, "I had always thought that that was the best approach." With regard to the matter of Assad being exiled to Russia, Assad can read the news too, and Putin knows that. If Putin has anybody in mind to replace Assad, Assad would get rid of that candidate immediately. This is assuming that Putin could depose Assad, which in my view is nearly impossible anyway. I think the hype about "Putin is willing to give asylum to Assad" doesn't mean anything. Putin hedged by saying that it was premature to talk about it, and that Assad might not have to leave Syria in any case. This is not an offer of asylum; it's a carefully worded reply to a reporter's question.

Slight chance of this happening given Putin's recent comments about granting asylum to al-Assad but still an unlikely occurrence at this point. Assad could be driven out of Syria but this seems unlikely while he is being supported by Russia and Iran who would lose face with this outcome (so a 10% chance). Putin has just said that Assad could be given asylum in Russia if he was rejected by the Syrian people in an election (so Putin has presumably considered the possibility and is maybe trying to see how the idea flies) but in order to have a real election a cease fire would be needed and its difficult to see how an election could be held in territory controlled by IS or other Islamic group who do not believe in the concept of democracy. So on the face of it Putin's idea does not seem to have any possibility of happening. However Putin does not say things without a reason, so the question is why did Putin mention elections at all? It could be that Putin has realised that his airpower is not going to win the war for Assad. If so the options are for Iran to send in large numbers of ground troops (which would upset the Sunni states and US), or Russia to send in a lot of ground troops, which could see Russia bogged down in an unwinnable war similar to what happened in Afghanistan in the 1980s or for some way be found so that Russia and Iran can get out of Syria without loss of face. A "peace" plan/cease fire with Assad "retiring" and some other figurehead taking over the Syrian government could be proposed. (A bit like the way that the US got out of Vietnam). Even this scenario is difficult to pull off as there is no sign of all parties being willing to talk, but Assad "retiring" could be seen as a concession. So there is maybe a 25% change that Putin will get Assad to "retire" in the next 14 months. (10% + 25% = 35%)

In 2012, rebel fighters captured at least one of the systems from the Syrian military.  ‘The Joint Chiefs believed that Assad should not be replaced by fundamentalists. The administration’s policy was contradictory. They wanted Assad to go but the opposition was dominated by extremists. So who was going to replace him? To say Assad’s got to go is fine, but if you follow that through – therefore anyone is better. It’s the “anybody else is better” issue that the JCS had with Obama’s policy.’ The Joint Chiefs felt that a direct challenge to Obama’s policy would have ‘had a zero chance of success’. So in the autumn of 2013 they decided to take steps against the extremists without going through political channels, by providing US intelligence to the militaries of other nations, on the understanding that it would be passed on to the Syrian army and used against the common enemy, Jabhat al-Nusra and Islamic State.

Updated forecast (downward): 
The UN Security Council resolution seems like a step forward. Yet, as indicated by the participants, many obstacles remain. Given that the resolution avoids the question of Assad’s fate, it appears to confirm earlier statements that he will remain in power for the immediate future. As indicated in my first forecast, any political settlement hinges on the timing and sequencing of key events. In this case, those events include a military cease-fire (meaning Syria’s opposition groups and Assad’s forces). If the cease-fire holds, then the process of putting together a political settlement begins. The very last phase would include elections and a transition. The answer to the question of whether Assad surrenders power before March 2017 is analogous to an international relations rubik’s cube – there are many permutations. Based on recent diplomatic activity, the probability of Assad remaining in power for the foreseeable future seems more likely.

The Russians and Iranians want influence over Syria, military bases (and for Iran the ability to transit weapons and material to Lebanon).  They don't have any particular loyalty to Assad himself.   If government forces in Syria are able to re-establish control, then Assad becomes a liability (both Syrians and the international community will be happier if he leaves and that could be the price of letting Russia and Iran control Syria).   The Russians can build him a nice dacha on the Crimean coast.   If the government forces lose more control and things get uglier, Assad will be the fall guy.  Either way I don't think he serves any useful purpose in the end game (though as a matter of principle the Russians and Iranians will want to keep him in the seat until the end game arrives or an alternative candidate is identified).  They will find one- money buys loyalty and the threat of Iranian/Russian reprisals against a turncoat will keep the candidate on the straight and narrow.  For me the main question is whether the "end game" will come by 1 March 2017.    I see an 80% chance it will, and an 80% chance that Assad is gone in that instance (hence 64%).

A look at the negotiating position of the rebel delegation slated to participate in the talks with the regime next month: http://yalibnan.com/2015/12/18/syrian-opposition-wants-transition-without-assad/ This quote from the story is interesting: "Riad Hijab, elected on Thursday as coordinator by an opposition body set up in Saudi Arabia last week, said Security Council resolutions and the Geneva 1 road map drawn up in 2012 provided for a political transition in Syria without the president and a transitional governing council with full executive powers. “We are going into negotiations on this principle, we are not entering talks (based on) anything else. There will be no concession,” he told reporters on Friday." Since the Geneva Communique prescribes  a "transitional governing body with full executive powers," and that means no "President," Assad will never agree to this. So there will be no settlement, since the negotiating positions of the regime and the rebels are basically incompatible. If either side backs down on this one issue, it's the equivalent of abandoning its entire position and caving in to the other side. But the negotiations may continue for a while because Assad will be perfectly happy to keep some rebels talking while he dispatches others in detail. So after months of manic diplomacy and meaningless semantic shifts in Russian pronouncements, what we'll probably see is some protracted negotiations which provide a breathing space for all sides, then a renewal of the fighting. There's a lot to say about the UN resolution, but I'm sure everyone has read it and has an opinion about its content. I think perhaps the most important thing is that the resolution permits "offensive and defensive" operations against al-Nusra, ISIS and other "terrorists" not party to the negotiations. The full list of unacceptable "terrorist" groups has not yet been finalized. Some rebel groups (presumably including militias) say they will not participate in the negotiations unless they have a timetable for Assad stepping down. There is no word if these groups will abide by the ceasefire.  If the ceasefire is implemented and holds, I think there will be no chance of Assad leaving within the time frame of this question, and probably not at all. I have thought all along that the only real possibility of this question closing as a "Yes" came from the possibility that a rebel offensive would induce Assad to flee Damascus. A ceasefire precludes that possibility for as long as it lasts.  I also doubt that Assad will break the ceasefire. He will have plenty of opportunities to grab chunks of territory that are fair game, and his interlocutors will have a much tougher time taking on ISIS and al-Nusra. They may wind up appealing to Assad, or Putin, for air cover. In short, the resolution is a win for Assad.

Despite the title, this article indicates that Assad doesn't really enjoy the prospect of a "cozy retirement." http://www.politico.com/story/2015/12/kerry-assad-syria-peace-talks-216911 Stephen Rapp, former U.S. Ambassador-at-Large for War Crimes Issues, with regard to Assad's "cozy retirement": "But you can't have an agreement that says they have a get-out-of-jail-free card and a permanent position of immunity." Which means you can't have an agreement. Western officials are bouncing back and forth about the issue of not indicting Assad before he leaves office. But some of them are leaving open the possibility of trying him after he leaves office. This is why Assad will never take a deal; even people who are willing to give him immunity will rescind that immunity as soon as they can get their hands on him. Iran or Russia could give Assad asylum, but either power would be under pressure to surrender him if they took him in. The best way for them to avoid the cost of sheltering him is to just leave him in place. It's not like they're paying any diplomatic price for siding with him; Iran just got the nuclear deal with the west, and Putin's prestige has never been higher. That may change. But western politicians' insistence on trying Assad probably won't. Here's another quote from the article: "I don't think I take a back seat to anybody on defending human rights in Syria," said Robert Ford, Obama's former ambassador to Damascus and a proponent of more aggressive support for Syria's moderate rebels. "But even I would say that if it would end the war six months earlier and save 15,000 lives, I think I would look at it." So Ford might not do it, but he'd look at it. A tepid assertion that you *might* consider immunity is not much reassurance if you're Assad. Assad is in a corner, and he can't be defeated, dislodged or persuaded to leave. Assad may slip in the shower and crack his skull, so my forecast is still at 15%. But muddled western diplomacy, the machinations of his allies, or the military operations of his enemies give no reason to think Assad will be deposed soon.

Below is a column from RT, written by an Irish journalist. I think it's a pretty safe bet that this reflects at least some segment of opinion inside the Kremlin.  https://www.rt.com/op-edge/326139-kerry-putin-syria-moscow/ I think an important quote is, "Russia has time and again rightly pointed out that Syria’s political future is for the Syrian people to decide as a matter of sovereignty." This addresses a matter that I don't think is given enough play in comments on this question. No one (including me) has commented on the recent history of Russian reactions to U.S. interventions abroad. During the Balkan interventions of the 1990s, Russia's position was that western intervention in Yugoslavia was illegal, arrogant, high-handed and a violation national sovereignty. Since then, Russia has been positioning itself as the champion of small countries resisting U.S. intervention, and dismissing U.S. and western moral justifications as a smokescreen for economic or other interests.  I have no interest is discussing the merits of Russia's position regarding intervention, but I bring it up because I think Russia's stance as defender of small counties' sovereignty makes it difficult for them to directly force any kind of settlement on Assad, let alone engineer his overthrow. They have not placed themselves in this role in order to throw it away; you can't be an unconditional supporter of national sovereignty and then overthrow an inconvenient client, or force a deal down his throat.  Russia may "declare victory and get out" between now an March 1, 2017, and if they did, that would change the situation drastically. I doubt if they'll do that within the time frame, however. States that project power don't accept humiliation lightly, and Putin would not want to show lack of resolve to his domestic jihadists. EDIT: This is kind of related: http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/12/17/U-N-war-crimes-team-will-not-investigate-foreign-air-strikes-in-Syria.html The gist of the story is that UN war crimes monitors will not investigate air strikes by foreign air forces. So the Syrians, who are legally sovereign in Syria, are to be investigated and held accountable by UN monitors, but westerners waging war in Syria, who have no legal standing to wage war there, will not be held accountable, or even investigated. Russia operates there at the request of the Syrian government, so does have legal standing, like it or not.

Let's give this question a fresh shot: 
- There are 14 months and change until March 1, 2017. Let's call it 15 months and divide them into a 3 month chunk and two subsequent 6 month chunks. Call these periods T1, T2, T3 
- The three methods in which this could get resolved are: a deal (scenario A), an assassination (B), a military defeat (C)
- Let's handle each of these separately.  (A) A deal that gets rid of Assad does not currently look likely (fractured opposition, lack of alternative, Russian support -- at least outwardly), but that may change as events unfold (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syria_peace_talks_in_Vienna). So let's assign a probability of 5% that this happens over the next 3 months (i.e T1). Raising the uncertainty, make it 10% over T2, and 15% over T3.  (B) Highly unpredictable from my perspective. Haven't seen very many of those in the Arab world lately. I assume he must be taking precautions against his combatant enemies, but what about an inside job. It would appear that for that to happen, the regime's situation would need to be dire, which with Russian help, it is not at the moment. Dropping 5 points. Below is a story from The Economist (it also appeared in other publications today) about Assad's complicity in war crimes. Not that it was news, but this shows why it is unlikely that Assad will agree to "retirement," since he will be immediately arrested. He might get asylum in Russia or Iran, and have some guarantee against prosecution. Perhaps not an airtight guarantee in either case, but it is true that neither Russia nor Iran would want to be perceived by prospective allies as so unreliable as to hand him over. The latest from Riyadh below. Highlight: no role for Assad or his top lieutenants, which pretty much puts the kibosh on the whole idea of a regime-rebel peace conference right there. Your initial negotiating position should always be more than your willing to settle for, but it can't be that your interlocutor should ultimately give you everything you want and then go away, or put himself at your mercy. This also kind of obviates the possibility of Russia or Iran getting rid of Assad and installing someone else. The Russians and Iranians would have to scour Syria (and Assad's prisons) to find a Syrian Konrad Adenauer, and even assuming such a person exists, he would have to be accepted by the regime supporters and the rebels. The reports out of Riyadh make it clear that the rebels are not fighting Assad personally, but the regime. They would consider the replacement of Assad strictly a cosmetic change. So the presence of Assad is not the impediment to peace, and never has been. The impediment to peace is that the factions in Syria have incompatible visions that do not lend themselves to a negotiated settlement. Even if Assad were eliminated, the regime would survive. Even if the regime were eliminated, the incompatible aims of the remaining factions would still not be reconciled. One faction, Ahrar al-Sham, walked out of the talks. It remains to be seen if they will sign on to the rebel negotiating position in the end, and if  abandoning the talks is just a negotiating tactic of its own. Initially, the talks were scheduled to continue until Friday, so Ahrar al-Sham may still attend if there is a session. But the walkout does demonstrate that there is no "rebel movement." There are disparate groups with specific goals and agendas, and they are not fighting in order to compromise, they are fighting to attain power.  Assad may cease to be President of Syria within the time frame of the question. But the most likely scenario that will close the question as a "Yes" will be rebel military action that forces Assad to retreat from Damascus to his coastal redoubt in Latakia. As things have been going so far, Assad is more likely to end up like Chiang-Kai-shek than Mussolini. From the press coverage since yesterday, it appears that if the U.S. struck a Syrian Army base it did so by mistake - or perhaps the mistake was by the Russian AF. Whatever the case, it appears that air assets aren't being deliberately used against Assad. Friendly fire by the Russians or mistaken targeting by the coalition is to be expected where rival zones of control are in such close proximity. I think the most significant thing about this raid is the expectation by some people in the west that air campaigns, and wars in general, be carried out with no civilian casualties. Here's the Guardian's coverage of another raid: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/07/syrian-civilians-killed-us-airstrike And there's the story from last month about warning the drivers of trucks carrying ISIS oil that their trucks were about to be bombed. http://www.snopes.com/2015/11/23/obama-dropped-leaflets-warning-isis-airstrikes/ http://www.military.com/daily-news/2015/11/19/us-choice-to-drop-leaflets-in-syria-contrasts-russian-way-war.html The spokesman in the Military.com article criticizes the Russian tactics of massive strikes with "dumb bombs," and I'm sure is point is well taken. But what he does not address is a) whether the truckers actually left or b) would it have made a difference? Would the strike have been cancelled if they had remained in place? In other words, was the warning Kabuki to get the U.S. off the hook for civilian casualties, or, if it was sincere, could ISIS have called the U.S. bluff? I don't think the coalition air campaign can survive very many strikes that inflict (or appear to inflict) high numbers of civilian casualties; the press, NGOs, and some politicians will demand that the campaign end, or be so curtailed as to be useless. Therefore, the regime will blame the coalition for any air strike that inflicts civilian casualties, and ISIS will do its utmost to insure civilian casualties, so as to discredit the coalition, or perhaps preempt strikes altogether just by presenting the risk. I consider it unlikely that the coalition air campaign will make any difference one way or the other. It may continue for a long time, but will be hampered by its own rules of engagement, and ISIS and regime exploitation of those rules. I think the big story this week is the Riyadh conference, which is also the story we will probably get the least information  about.

FP’s Colum Lynch and John Hudson report that Saudi Arabia has invited Syrian militants Ahrar al-Sham -- which has in the past allied with al Qaeda affiliate al Nusra Front -- along with more than 90 other Syrian opposition representatives to Riyadh this week. The meeting is intended as a prep session “before big-power political talks that are scheduled for Dec. 18 in New York, according to diplomats based at the United Nations who have been briefed on the plans.” Problem is, Moscow isn’t buying it. Russia says that it wants Ahrar al-Sham added to the list of terrorist organizations that are excluded from the peace talks…. Turkey and Iraq are locked in a diplomatic spat over Turkey's deployment of troops to a base in Iraq near Mosul. On Friday, Turkey sent hundreds of troops, including armor and artillery to the northern Iraqi town of Bashiqa, where the Turks have a training facility to train local forces in the fight against the Islamic State. Iraq has said the deployment is an illegal breach of its sovereignty and is threatening to take Turkey's move to the U.N. Security Council should it persist. Turkish officials, however, claim the move is simply a reinforcement of the preexisting training facility…. Turkish photographs caught sight of a Russian sailor brandishing a shoulder-fired surface to air missile as his ship, the Russian navy's Caesar Kunikov, sailed through the Bosphorous Strait in Turkey. The move, an apparent threat to Turkish aircraft, comes after a Turkish F-16 downed a Russian Su-24 fighter jet last month, which Turkey accused of violating its airspace. Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said the move was "pure provocation," according to the BBC. Turkish defense contractor Aselsan is now in talks with Ukraine to upgrade its tanks, artillery and personnel carriers, Defense News reports. The move appears to be the latest in the tit-for-tat retaliation between Turkey and Russia after Turkey's downing of a Russian Su-24 near the Turkish-Syrian border. Since the Saudis are going to try to forge a rebel negotiating front starting next week, and regime-rebel talks are supposed to begin in January, I think it's worth it to look back at these two articles from September and October. Both propose the Bosnian settlement as a solution, and I think such a solution may result from the talks - assuming the talks do not break down or indefinitely stall. Notice that the Dayton Accord included the signature, and required the acceptance, of Slobodan Milosevic, who was considered the Assad of his day. Milosevic was ultimately overthrown, but by a domestic uprising, not by outside military action. If next year political leaders and foreign ministers start talking about Bosnia as a precedent for Syria, I think we can expect one of two things: everyone will hold their nose and Assad will be a party to any settlement, or the possibility of a settlement that includes Assad will cause the rebels to abandon the negotiations. Links below. http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2015-09-14/syria-at-peace-to-imagine-it-think-of-bosnia- http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/world-view-dayton-accord-offers-a-possible-route-out-of-syrian-disaster-1.2385965

Updated Forecast: Based on an absence of momentum toward a political transition, a minor adjustment of my original forecast is necessary (30%).  With no advancement toward a political transition, the souring of relations between Russia and Turkey, and the focus on ISIS over Assad, the probability of an Assad-free Syria by March 2017 appears even less likely.  
Interestingly, Deputy Secretary of State Tony Blinken provided an optimistic assessment of the civil war this week (1 December), stating that the chances of a political transition in Syria were better than "at any time during this crisis."  See: http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/12/01/top-u-s-diplomat-political-solution-to-syria-civil-war-now-in-sight/
As you read this article, you'll notice that for Blinken to be correct, his (possibly the State Department's as well) assessment of the Russian position in the conflict must be accurate. Over the last 20 years (at least), the U.S. has a poor record of calibrating its diplomacy with Russian interests. With all due respect to Secretary Blinken, I don't believe we are turning the corner in Syria any time soon.

http://bigstory.ap.org/article/e72f2dc4a38b47f8a25f279522b3b4d7/told-he-must-go-syrias-assad-may-outlast-obama-office  "Bashar Assad's presidency looks likely to outlast Barack Obama's. "As the United States has turned its attention to defeating the Islamic State group, it has softened its stance on the Syrian leader. More than four years ago, Obama demanded that Assad leave power. Administration officials later said Assad did not have to step down on "Day One" of a political transition. Now, they are going further. "A peace plan agreed to last weekend by 17 nations meeting in Vienna says nothing about Assad's future, but states that "free and fair elections would be held pursuant to the new constitution within 18 months." To clarify the timeline, the State Department said this past week that the clock starts once Assad's representatives and opposition figures begin talks on a constitution. The vote would determine a new parliament, though not necessarily a new president. "Getting to constitutional talks will be difficult. It implies that Syria's warring parties first reach a cease-fire and establish a transition government — something unattainable so far. Neither Syria's government nor its fractured opposition has endorsed the strategy yet or done much to advance it. "Nothing can start before defeating the terrorists who occupy parts of Syria," Assad recently told Italian state television. Assad considers anyone fighting him, including moderate rebels, to be terrorists. "Obama countered: "I do not foresee a situation in which we can end the civil war in Syria while Assad remains in power. ... Even if I said that was OK, I still don't think it would actually work. You could not get the Syrian people, the majority of them, to agree to that kind of outcome. And you couldn't get a number of their neighbors to agree to that outcome, as well."
. . . 
" . . .  Unlike IS, Assad has powerful patrons in Moscow and Tehran. Russian airstrikes since September have helped stiffen the Syrian government's defenses, while Iranian forces and proxy Hezbollah militants have added muscle to its ground operations.
. . . 
"The Nov. 14 statement from the Vienna talks, involving the U.S., Russia, Saudi Arabia, Iran and more than a dozen other governments, . . . does not outline which opposition groups can negotiate with Assad and which are considered terrorist groups. Assad isn't even mentioned.. . .  By itself, the plan offers no clear path for Assad's departure, raising the prospect of the embattled Syrian leader still in office when Obama's presidency ends on Jan. 20, 2017. "Western diplomats described a poker game being played between the U.S. and its own allies. U.S. officials said that while they accept the idea that Assad won't leave office immediately, the plan for his exit will have to be clarified as part of the diplomatic process. "Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey are being counted on to persuade the Syrian opposition to support the plan, but will only do so if they get a guarantee on Assad. The U.S. and its European partners cannot offer that guarantee, according to the diplomats, who were not authorized to discuss the talks publicly and spoke on condition of anonymity. "If the opposition rejects talking, Assad will not resign as a result. The rebels would not gain sufficient strength to defeat him on the battlefield, and Russia and Iran would not stop supporting him. "Even if the plan is accepted by all and works to the best of expectations, Assad would be appear locked in for a transition process that could extend deep into 2017 or longer.If after 18 months or two years, IS is defeated and calm is restored, opposition groups would risk reigniting Syria's conflict by reasserting demands for Assad's ouster. World and regional powers would face the same quandary. For these reasons, some Western diplomats have begun talking about the possibility of Assad staying on indefinitely as a ceremonial president, though stripped of his control over the nation's security and intelligence apparatuses. It's unclear whether any of the sides in the fighting would see that as an acceptable compromise.

I'm raising the odds of Assad's exit -- a little.  Assad has a strong will to remain in power, firm backing from his political constituency, and Russian support.  This will help him resist.  However, forces that believe Assad's departure is required for a political settlement, now believe they have a chance to turn Russia and change the situation.  Unfortunately, the political realities of factions and forces within Syria will continue to make this difficult.  Excessive focus on Assad's departure fails to address the legitimate existential concerns of his constituency.   Excessive focus on destruction of ISIS, also fails to acknowledge the absence of any credible government succession option.  Beyond that, Putin is no pushover.  Today he called the downing of a Russian jet, "a stab in the back" by forces who support terrorism. In this context, words of hope for a grand coalition to destroy ISIS, unseat Assad, and unveil a tidy political solution, seem like magical thinking.   Obama promises intensification, but this term appears to have little meaning.   Maybe he could get somewhere if he changed his own position on unseating Assad and instead figured out how to guarantee security for Assad and his people in a reconstituted (possibly partitioned) Syria.  Obama always hurts himself with the conviction that he's the smartest guy in the room.  Guys who think they are the smartest guys in the room, can be the biggest obstacles to successful negotiation.

ISTANBUL 23NOV15— Turkish fighter jets on patrol near the Syrian border on Tuesday shot down a Russian warplane that Turkey said had ignored numerous warnings and violated its airspace, in a long-feared escalation that will further strain relations between the NATO member country and Russia. NATO announced that it would hold an emergency meeting on Tuesday in Brussels to discuss the episode, as credible reports were emerging from Latakia Province, where the Russian jet went down, that rebels possibly wielding TOW antitank missiles and other weapons had shot down a Russian helicopter sent to the scene of the crash to look for survivors. In his first remarks on the incident, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia confirmed that an F-16 Turkish fighter jet had shot down the Russian plane, a Sukhoi Su-24, with an air-to-air missile. But he insisted that the Russian jet had been in Syrian airspace at the time. - NYT 24NOV15

(inching up slightly 81% to 85%) The events today might be fodder for turning Russia re: Assad. --> http://www.vox.com/2015/11/24/9790990/turkey-russia-plane-shootdown EXCERPT: One important question is whether this will have any ramifications for the international peace talks to end Syria's war. Russia has been making ever-so-tentative signals that it might be willing to make some real concessions to end the war, maybe even help to nudge out Assad. This incident, then, could lead Russia to conclude that its Syria involvement is getting too costly. While Russian leaders don't really, as a rule, admit mistakes — that's not how they teach it in the Moscow school of diplomacy, as I heard one senior US official put it — there are indications that it was beginning to see its Syria intervention as a mistake. A number of Russians have reportedly died in the fighting, and they don't have much to show for it. In October, Russian and Iranian forces helped Assad's army launch a big military campaign to retake territory from the rebels — and it largely failed. Russia's Syria intervention is unpopular at home, and Putin is extremely sensitive to public opinion. A September poll by Moscow's Levada Center found that only 39 percent of respondents said they supported Russia's policy toward the Assad regime. When asked what Russia should do for Assad, 69 percent opposed direct military intervention. A tiny 14 percent of respondents said that Russia should send troops or other direct military support to Syria. That's a pretty sharp contrast to Russia's policy toward Ukraine, which has been enormously popular with Russians. Putin's first, second, and third concerns have always been to maintain his own rule at home. With the economy in shambles, public opinion is crucial for that. Now that footage is emerging of a dead Russian pilot, Russian public opinion could become even more skeptical of the Syria intervention. And Putin will likely respond to that. At the same time, this could lead Putin to harden his position on Syria — to seek to raise the stakes and make this about avenging Russian honor as a means to shore up public support for the war. That's probably not the most likely outcome, but it is a possibility. \\\\\

The important factor for Assad's ability to remain alive and in power in Damascus is news that one of the insurgent groups attacking the capitol city is considering a ceasefire. Sources: Dateline 11-19-15 A powerful Syrian insurgent group said on Thursday it was studying a local ceasefire proposal tabled by an international mediator aimed at halting fighting near Damascus. Brief but interesting glimpse of events in eastern Syria: http://syriadirect.org/news/activist-ypg-practices-%E2%80%98collective%E2%80%99-punishment-against-al-hasakah-arabs/ Assuming large scale Kurdish success, (which may well happen) I would expect them to stop at the Euphrates, which makes a natural southern border for an incipient Kurdistan. The Kurds' war aim is the establishment of Kurdistan, either as a sovereign nation or as an autonomous sub-national entity. It's hard to imagine them marching against Damascus or points west after they have destroyed one of their principal enemies. The only likely target for the Kurds in the west in the Afrin enclave northwest of Aleppo, and abutting the Turkish border. But to break through to this pocket, they would not have to engage regime troops.  There's also this: http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2015/dec/03/syrian-kurds-are-winning/ The NYRB article demonstrates that alliances and truces are extremely changeable in Syria, in the east and elsewhere. Obviously, the only reliable way to predict events is to try to determine the motives and goals of the various sides, and decide how any given course of action would advance those goals. And even that can be tricky, because motives and goals can change as opportunities change. But I think it's reasonable to assume that the goal of the Kurds is the establishment of Kurdistan, and the Kurds will not engage in actions that they consider peripheral to that goal. The Kurds' two principal enemies as ISIS and Turkey. Assad is not any higher than third on the list, and he may be even lower down on it. Every fighter or vehicle sent west to engage the regime in a fighter or vehicle unavailable to defend Kurdistan if needed.

"According to our experts, a homemade explosive device equivalent to 1 kilogram of TNT went off onboard,” he said, explaining why the plane broke up in the air. This is a 4-dimensional chess question, but here goes! Necessary/Sufficient Conditions: (France, Iran Syria, Turkey, US, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon)
--Assad needs an acceptable refuge for himself, family, & entourage. France can provide.
--Russia needs assurance that it's naval base is secure and enduring. An MOU between all parties can guarantee Russian long term use of the base. (France, Iran, Turkey)
--Funding commitments MUST be made for refugees in Jordan, Turkey. and Lebanon. The EU and most other parties will agree. It's in their best interest.
--ISIL must be contained, and perceived to be degraded.  Likely to occur over the next few months as logistics becomes the weak spot of ISIL.
--A framework for new governance must be established. There's no way to put Humpty Dumpty together again, so a structure of Swiss like cantons is the best solution, with autonomy for Kurds, Alawites, Sunnis, Druze, etc.
--The EU will seek pathways to actions that reduce the flow of refugees. 
WILDCARDS:
--Israel will not interfere as long as Syria remains weak and does not pose a threat.
--KSA & Gulf states should not try to interfere because they have enough problems internally and in Yemen
--UN Security Council could approve a "Responsibility to Protect" resolution that authorizes military force in Syria.
--Kurdistan President Barzani could make a push to incorporate Syrian Kurds in an independent state, but he is smart enough not to seriously anger Turkey & Iran right now. Is all of this diplomacy possible, and will it get Assad out of power in the next year or so? Yes.
