I fail to see any particular significance in the new Russian proposal. As the BBC article points out, much of it is just a retread of the Geneva communique of three years ago. The BBC piece also details many of the obstacles to any peace plan. I consider the Russian proposal to be so much boilerplate. None of it has any immediate significance, nor is it intended to. In my opinion, Russia's proposal, and all Russian public statements so far, have two specific goals: first, to delegitimize any rebel groups that Russia wants to marginalize, perhaps giving Russia a chance to co-opt some rebel groups, and second, to legitimize the idea of Assad remaining in power, even if that power is tightly constrained. There are quite a few questions that are not clear when taking about Russia's moves in Syria. For example, does Russia consider the reconstitution of Syria feasible? If so, does Russia consider it desirable? I think the answer to the first question is "probably not," and the answer to the second is, "yes, but conditionally." They are interested in their strategic goals, which they will pursue with or without Assad. If it is advantageous to get rid of him, they will do so, or try to. But so far nothing I have read here or elsewhere has made any kind of case that the Russians consider it to their advantage to get rid of Assad at this time. That may change, but so far there is nothing on the horizon to think that it will. The Russians know that their best hope of permanently securing bases on the Mediterranean coast is for Assad to retain control of Latakia, at the very least. There is so far no one to replace him. It is unlikely that the rebels will come up with any alternative. There may be candidates within Assad's ruling circle, but installing such a person is a risk. Why would Assad's coalition accept such a move? What if they didn't? Who do the Russians back then? What do they do? Send more troops? Pull out, having accomplished nothing? For now, Assad is the path of least resistance, and he will be for the foreseeable future. Unless there is some definite alternative to Assad (and there isn't), Russia faces a very difficult scenario if it engages in any heavy-handed king-making.

Russia is expected to propose an eight-point plan to end Syria’s civil war at talks in Vienna later this week, according to documents obtained by Reuters. The plan would include an 18-month constitutional reform process including members of the Syrian regime and opposition and would conclude with early elections. The proposal does not mandate that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad step down or refrain from participating in elections, a potential sticking point for the plan, but does state that Assad “will not chair the constitutional commission." A spokesperson for the Russian Foreign Ministry refused to discuss the document with Reuters and said that no proposal was being prepared for the talks this week. Western officials were skeptical of the leaked plan, particularly its allowance for Assad to run for re-election. "The document does not suit a lot of people,” an anonymous official told Reuters. On Monday, British Foreign Secretary reiterated the demand that a transition process mandate Assad leaving power. "We do not believe that it is going to be possible to bring the opposition groups into the political process and have an effective ceasefire unless we have a clear point at which President Assad will depart,” he told reporters at the United Nations. Separately, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan renewed his call for implementing a no-fly zone in Syria today and said he would raise the issue at a meeting of the G20 in Antalya, Turkey, this week. -Foreign Policy, The Middle East Channel, 11NOV15 -------------------------------------------------- Yes, Russia figures ALL this out in advance. I have several assumptions for this forecast, the main ones being that Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah will continue support for the regime at current levels, that the U.S. involvement will not extend into direct targeting of Syrian government forces, and that IS and/or opposition forces will not be able make significant territorial gains at the expense of the territory controlled by the Assad government. Also, I assume that Assad is unlikely to vacate his office on his own volition while being backed by the aforementioned foreign backers. International actors could step up efforts to force Assad to leave and any indication of this, or the falsification of the assumptions above, would prompt a revision of the forecast. With all that said, I suppose Assad could simply die prematurely (given his age, if he were American, he would have approximately 16% chance of dying a premature death--I give him better odds at surviving natural causes because I assume his health is monitored, he has better than average access to health care, and has tight security). I suppose the biggest risk for him is being assassinated, incapacitated, or forced out of office because of the reasons mentioned above, so I'll put his chances of ceasing to be president at 21% for now.

At the initial talks in Vienna on Oct. 30, the U.S., Russia, Iran and more than a dozen other nations agreed to launch a new peace effort involving Syria's government and opposition groups. But they carefully avoided the issue of when Assad might leave power — a dispute at the heart of the nearly five-year-old conflict that has claimed more than 250,000 lives.
British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond said there is "quite a lot going on" behind the scenes ahead of this weekend's talks, and U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry "is highly active in trying to promote this process." But Hammond stressed to reporters at U.N. headquarters in New York that no one should underestimate "the scale of the challenge."
Hammond cited the "fundamental difference" between Britain, the U.S. and other countries that believe Assad must leave office as part of the transition process, and Syrian allies Russia and Iran "who believe that he should be able to take part in a future election and if that election decides that he should go, then he goes at that point.

There was an interesting exchange between American Senator Lindsay Graham (who was showboating for his Presidential bid) and a number of key administration players on the Syria file during one of those endless House committees recently. Graham was trying to develop a sound bite about Obama's policy on equipping fighters to fight not ISIL, but the combined Assad group of Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah. He was pressing for details on a possible shift of strategy away from taking down Assad, the prior held strategy. Not one administration representative would answer, because if they did confirm that the fight to remove Assad remains the objective, Graham would have teed up his sound bite, "in which case we are going to war with Russia and Iran by proxy in Syria". Which would be obvious. It was clear to me that the administration fully understands that any new effort at equipping rebels for anything but a fight against ISIL would indeed be just that proxy war.  It seems to me the Americans have been outflanked in Syria by Russia's intervention, they know it, and have surrendered the field rather than be dragged into a close conflict with Russia and Iran. They may still supply and equip covertly through their Arab allies, but can and will do nothing that meaningfully provides any kind of military support to the embattled Syrian rebel groups fighting Assad, Russia, and Iran. This does not bode well for those groups whose objective remains the fall of Assad, and thereby decreases the likelihood of Assad's removal by these rebel groups.

There seems to be a growing consensus among the key players that a negotiated settlement to the Syrian civil war is needed before Assad steps down from power.  In this scenario, Assad remains in power until a negotiated settlement with opposition forces is reached. At that time, the various powers involved seem to be signaling Assad should go within 6 months. At some point, a transitional government enters the scene. Of course, many questions and challenges remain. For one thing, a negotiated settlement implies a cessation of violence. It is not necessary for all fighting to stop – as ISIS will likely never agree to any settlement. However, a cessation of violence between Syrian opposition forces and Assad’s military is required. The next question is who is doing the negotiating on behalf of rebel forces? These challenges are Syrian-specific. The intricacies of the diplomatic power struggle over the Syrian Civil war represents another layer of uncertainty: Russian intervention, Saudi Arabia/Iranian tensions, US/Russia tensions, US/Iranian tensions, Turkey, the E.U. and the refugee crisis, Jordan, and the UAE. It’s a hornets nest to say the least.  According to recent news sources, John Kerry indicated that Assad should go at some point, but talks must continue. In addition, today’s (30 October) WSJ reported that:  ‘The agreement, reached on Friday after seven hours of discussions, is meant to advance talks on a new constitution and elections, a process now backed for the first time by regional and international powers, including Russia, U.S., Iran and Saudi Arabia.
The joint statement concluding the talks didn’t explicitly mention Mr. Assad, saying Syria’s “state institutions will remain intact.” Mr. Assad isn’t excluded from the process of drafting a new constitution and organizing U.N.-supervised free elections leading to what the statement called “credible, inclusive, non-sectarian governance.” The Syrian political situation in 2017 hinges on the sequencing and timing of key events – agreements between powers, agreements with opposition forces, process for transitional government, military decisions, etc.  None of the aforementioned variables for a political outcome has taken shape at this point. Until a better understanding emerges on some of these key areas, the probability of Assad not being in power needs to be set accordingly.

Still holding at 30%, and even that is only because of the condition that Assad not be driven from Damascus for more then three weeks. I don't think the Vienna talks have any significance at all at this time. Some news stories have highlighted indications that neither Russia or Iran is "wedded" to the idea of Assad remaining indefinitely. Of course they're not. Neither one of them is supporting him as a favor to him. They are doing it because the consider it to be to their advantage. Iran wants hegemony over as much of the Middle East as it can get, and Russia wants the ability to project power into the eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East. It's worth noting that the objectives of Russia and Iran are not really compatible, but they'll both worry about that later. From the article linked by @einsteinjs below: 'A senior official from the Middle East familiar with the Iranian position suggested Iran might go as far as ending support for Assad after the transition period. "Talks are all about compromises and Iran is ready to make a compromise by accepting Assad remaining for six months," the official told Reuters. "Of course, it will be up to the Syrian people to decide about the country's fate."' The "senior official" is obviously Iranian, because no allies of Iran were present at the Vienna meeting, and the quote is presented as authoritative. The important thing about this statement is that it's circular. Assad has to leave after a transition. But the country's fate is up to the "Syrian people," and if the "Syrian people" (whoever they are defined to be) want Assad to stick around in some capacity, he won't have to leave after the transition, because that's not the will of the Syrian people. As it is presented in the article, the statement is meaningless; it says two mutually exclusive things, with neither being defined as outweighing the other. I think there has developed in recent decades a great gap between the way the west looks at negotiations, and the way other cultures (including Russia) do. The west negotiates to reach a compromise, other powers negotiate to get what they want. To the west, negotiation is worthwhile in itself, to Iran or Russia, negotiation is worthwhile only so far as it advances specific policies that the leaders have agreed upon. I don't think that the public statements of Russia or Iran - especially  about Assad leaving after a transition - can be taken at face value. They know how westerners talk, and they're perfectly happy to talk that way in public. When it comes to actually making a deal, they will drive a much harder bargain. None of this means they won't kill, depose or otherwise abandon Assad. But they won't do it because the west asked them to.

Good link from @Heffalump below. I agree with Secretary Kerry that Russia and the U.S. do have  a lot of common ground. The important part of the article comes at the very end: '“Russia and the US share an amazing amount of common ground,” Kerry said. He noted that both sides agree on the need for a political solution; that victory by IS has to be prevented; on the imperative to save the state of Syria and its institutions; to preserve a united and secular Syria; and to create conditions for the return of displaced persons and refugees. "We agree on the right of the Syrian people to choose their leadership through transparent, free, and fair elections with a new constitution and protections for all minorities in the country," Kerry added.' So: "both sides agree on the need for a political solution; that victory by IS has to be prevented." Every other condition Kerry specifies is unworkable and no longer on the table. Syria will never be reconstituted in its current form. The best they can do is a cobble together a loose federation of cantons that will be called "Syria," have embassies around the world, and be accredited to international organizations. Saving Syrian institutions under a unified secular government is never going to happen. When Kerry, or anybody else, talks about "the Syrian people" choosing their leaders, it simply postpones the essential question of who "the Syrian people" actually are. By comparison, who are the "Lebanese people?" Maronites, Druze, Shi'ites, Sunnis, etc. as groups? Are they one nation? They don't seem to think so. So who are the "Syrians," and what form will their "choice" take? One person, one vote, or a divvying up of power among groups? Probably the latter, since the "protection of minorities" (including Alawites!) is specifically mentioned as a condition. So where does that leave us? With a political solution that prevents an ISIS victory. That's the only thing everybody can agree on, and in order to implement it, you have to go to the lowest common denominator. The lowest common denominator is that all the factions hammer out an agreement delineating their respective turf, stop fighting each other, and together turn on ISIS. I might add that this is an extremely far-fetched scenario, but I think that's what Kerry, Russia, Iran, et al. are after, because it's the best solution they can get. The alternative is a war that will literally last decades and metastasize throughout the region.

Assad says he won't consider such a deal until "terrorism is eradicated," but then Assad is the one who decides when that condition is fulfilled, so he can change his mind about an FSA alliance at any time. The second thing is the mention of Russian air power pounding rebel positions in central Hama (by which they mean Hama province; Hama city is held by Assad). The direct route to Aleppo from regime-held territory is through rebel-held areas of Hama province and Idlib province. @mike97mike is right about the importance of Safira to continued regime presence in Aleppo. The other areas cut off by ISIS are not contiguous with ISIS territory, and from the map look like that can be retaken by the regime fairly soon. Safira is different, because it is not isolated from ISIS-controlled territory, and ISIS troops can be reinforced and supplied there, although they are still vulnerable to air strikes. If Safira falls, I doubt if there will be a Stalingrad-style surrender of Assad troops in Aleppo. I assume they will be able to withdraw to positions south of Safira, and ISIS will not have the strength to destroy them. In my opinion the fall of Safira to ISIS, even if it happens, does the rebels no good. It just means that the rebels will be ISIS' sole opponent in the Aleppo area. Every advance by ISIS increases the danger to every adversary ISIS has. When ISIS has finished its offensive against opponent A, it launches an offensive against opponent B. When opponents A and B fight each other, ISIS moves in to any weak point it can exploit. I think it is reaching a point where at least some opposition groups might be willing to temporarily align with Assad against the threat of ISIS.  If such an alignment were to happen, it might permit the regime to open a western supply line from Hama to Aleppo, making Safira less vital. If the rebels reject the proposal, the Russians and the regime will spare no effort to open such a supply line anyway, probably in conjunction with a push toward Idlib, which started last month but may have stalled - in any case it's isn't in the news anymore. I agree with everyone that this battle is important, but I disagree with much of the commentary about what it means. I don't think that a withdrawal from Aleppo would mean the end of the regime, although it would obviously be a serious loss. But I might add that if the regime holds on in Safira, I think it has a pretty good chance of retaking Aleppo, or at least surrounding it. As always, the real problem is the complete lack of information about the composition of the forces of the various factions.

"So far, the group [IS] has gained control of approximately 10 loyalist checkpoints along the crucial supply line running from Hama through Salamiyeh, Ithriyah and Khanaser to Aleppo. Damascus and its allies have been forced to temporarily halt most of their offensive operations in Aleppo province as they scramble to secure the threatened corridor. The situation, already troubling for Syrian President Bashar al Assad, has only worsened with the rumors of the Islamic State's advances in al-Safira. If true, the group's latest push could threaten to cut supplies off from the large number of loyalist troops in Aleppo province. Though the troops could still receive deliveries flown in by aircraft, the loss of overland supply routes would be a heavy blow. The Islamic State's advances also highlight a broader reality of the Syrian civil war: As the rebels and loyalists continue to devote the bulk of their resources to fighting each other, the Islamic State will have the chance to take advantage of weaknesses in both fronts. For instance, in the initial stages of the Syrian government's latest offensive campaign, rebel forces weakened their lines of contact with the Islamic State to send reinforcements to Hama, Idlib and southern Aleppo. This decision enabled the Islamic State to push forward and take considerable territory in northern Aleppo province. Similarly, loyalist troops have focused the bulk of their attention on launching offensive operations against the country's rebels, giving the Islamic State the opportunity to advance against weakly held loyalist positions. Ultimately, al Assad's troops cannot allow their only supply line into Aleppo province to be closed off. If they did, they would risk the gradual weakening of their northern forces, dooming hopes of turning the tide of battle in their favor with the intervention of Russian troops. Their push to relieve besieged loyalist forces in Kweiris air base would also become much less significant if those troops were to be besieged once again within a larger loyalist pocket. Thus, reopening the supply lines into Aleppo will likely become the government's highest priority. Whether it is able to reopen those lines within a few days or its efforts stall in the face of the Islamic State's determined resistance will make the difference between temporary setback and potential catastrophe." - Stratfor  27OCT15

The geopolitical complexities and hostilities that recent Russian activity in Syria is causing could potentially lead to Russia's eventual support of a political transition in Syria.  This would have the dual effect of legitimizing Russia's geopolitical strategy in the area, (Russia's critics would be largely appeased, since the general sentiment in the world, towards Russia, would be "Russia did what the US had been trying to do for years yet had failed to do: eradicate ISIS AND affect regime change") and giving their military presence and campaign in Syria geopolitical clout.  It is unlikely, though, that Russia would support an election to find a replacement, and is instead more likely to support an presidentially-appointed successor to Assad.  In this scenario, Russia would/could convince Assad that resignation in this manner was in his best interest, as it would allow Assad to live a relatively comfortable life post-Presidency, free from being pursued for criminal charges by the ICC, and such a move would give Russia the political capital to play a big role in the choosing of a replacement to Assad, primarily, one who is largely pro-Russian, something which would be vital to Russia's geopolitical strategy.   So while Russia does want President Assad to stay in power, Russia is incredibly forward-thinking, and, as it applies to Bashar al-Assad in Syria, may already see the writing on the wall: eventually, Assad has got to go.  There is just no place for him in this increasingly-connected, cooperational, and peaceful world.  Knowing this, Russia may well decide to get ahead of the curve, and actually push for regime change in Syria.  However, that regime would necessarily need to be as "pro-Russian" as Assad is, if not more so, for Russia to support it, and that means that Russia cannot afford to risk that the regime change in question would come about through an election.   Therefore, it is far more likely that Assad will NOT cease to be President of Syria by 1 March, 2017.  Objectively, Russia is better off with Assad in power than any other potential political solution, but the Syria civil war has been going on for over 4 years now, and every day that it continues, a future with Assad in power becomes less-and-less likely.  Once that likeliness bottoms out, and reaches the point of no-return, change will likely be swift and precipitous.  Thus, we can be pretty sure that Assad will not be gone by March 2017, but we cannot be very-sure.  There is at least a reasonable chance that it could happen.

Here is how I break that question down:
I envision 3 main ways for him to cease to be the President of Syria:
1) His death - Bashar al-Assad is relatively young, having just turned 50, which makes his death by natural causes relatively unlikely. He could also die from an accident (as happened to his elder brother), or he could be the victim of an assassination. None of those possibilities seem likely.
2) His resignation/deposition while the Ba'ath Party stays in power. Again, not very likely.
3) The Syrian Civil War ends with rebels overthrowing the government. Seems the more likely of the three scenarios. However, the war has already lasted almost 5 years and doesn't seem to be clearly moving towards the end. For that reason, I think it is more likely that the rebels are not going to be able to seize power until March 2017.

I'm still sticking to my 30% forecast. But I'm posting because I think this link is interesting, especially in the light of tomorrow's Vienna meeting. http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/10/22/Putin-Syrian-government-Kurdish-forces-should-be-united.html I hope that link posts correctly because it's separate stories, one from August and one from this week. The first story concerns ISIS and the anti-Assad rebels fighting for control of the supply route from Turkey. Since the story was written there has been a third contender for control, namely regime forces along with Iran/Hezbollah troops, with the support of Russian air power. The second story presents Assad as being willing to compromise with "some" rebels. I think tomorrow's meeting will involve an offer by Putin to guarantee some concessions to Saudi and Turkish backed rebels in exchange for some indication that everyone accepts that Assad can stick around until some unspecified time in he future. Putin's threat is that the offensive against the northern supply route will continue, and almost certainly succeed, and the non-ISIS rebels will be defeated anyway. Thus if the rebels don't align with Assad, they will be cut off, and left to be destroyed by ISIS - not destroyed by Assad - the more horrific the retaliation against the rebels, the better for him. Saudi Arabia and Turkey are important because SA is the financier (with others) of the supplies, and Turkey is the conduit. The rebels are pretty much stuck with any deal those two powers make on their behalf, or at their expense. I think there are two things going on here. First, Russia has elbowed Iran out of the dominant position as Assad's sponsor - which Assad is perfectly fine with for now. Second, Putin and Assad are offering Syria (and the world) two options, and only two: Assad or ISIS.  As to the ultimate fate of Assad, I think he and Putin both think that he may be able to hold on forever if some compromise is reached soon with some rebel factions. I note something specific from this story about Turkey linked yesterday by REGallahue: http://news.yahoo.com/turkey-ready-accept-six-month-transition-period-syrias-132858752.html;_ylt=AwrC0CMa2SdWqwUA6hDQtDMD;_ylu=X3oDMTByNXQ0NThjBGNvbG8DYmYxBHBvcwM1BHZ0aWQDBHNlYwNzcg-- It states that the Turks might be content for Assad to continue in office for six months during a transition, but that there is no agreement as to when the six months might begin. There is an awful lot of hedging and equivocation by all parties right now. When people talk about a "transition" (which neither Putin nor Assad did - check the transcript) they can mean any number of things, and it is possible that no two parties will mean exactly the same thing.

زيارة الوداع تمهد لترتيبات في سورية تتجاهل إيران واشنطن تنتقد استقبال موسكو الرسمي للأسد
عنصر في الدفاع المدني يحمل طفلة أصيبت في قصف للنظام على إدلب (رويترز)
عنصر في الدفاع المدني يحمل طفلة أصيبت في قصف للنظام على إدلب (رويترز) موسكو: أشرف الصباغ 2015-10-22 1:19 AM      اعتبر مراقبون سياسيون الزيارة السرية للرئيس السوري بشار الأسد لموسكو أمس، بداية لحل سياسي يرتكز إلى الاستغناء عنه خلال مدة محددة يمكن الاتفاق عليها في إطار اللقاءات التي يتم الترتيب لها بين واشنطن والرياض وأنقرة وموسكو متجاهلة إيران.
وبينما أطلق المراقبون عليها "زيارة الوداع"، ذهبوا إلى إمكانية أن تكون موسكو قد وصلت إلى مرحلة التمهيد لإبعاد الأسد من أجل بدء تسويات سياسية تحظى بإجماع سوري.
وفي سياق ذي صلة، أطلع الرئيس الروسي فلاديمير بوتين في اتصال هاتفي الملك سلمان على تفاصيل المباحثات التي جرت مع النظام السوري، إضافة إلى الأوضاع في المنطقة ومستجدات الأحداث على الساحتين الإقليمية والدولية. في زيارة سرية إلى موسكو، لم يتم الكشف عنها إلا بعد انتهائها، أطلع رأس النظام السوري بشار الأسد نظيره الروسي، فلاديمير بوتين، على الأوضاع والخطط المستقبلية للجيش السوري. وقال الأسد موجها حديثه إلى الرئيس الروسي إن الجميع يفهم أن أي تحركات عسكرية لابد أن تتبعها خطوات سياسية، معربا عن أمله بأن تتابع موسكو ودمشق عملية إعادة بناء سورية اقتصاديا وسياسيا.
أما بوتين فهو لا يزال يرى أن موسكو تنطلق من التطورات الإيجابية في العمليات القتالية، التي يرى أنها "سوف تقود في نهاية المطاف إلى التوصل لتسوية طويلة الأمد، على أساس عملية سياسية، بمشاركة كل القوى السياسية الدينية والإثنية، والكلمة الأخيرة في هذا الشأن يجب أن تبقى للشعب السوري فقط". كما أكد أيضا على أن روسيا جاهزة للإدلاء بدلوها، ليس فقط في العملية العسكرية ضد الإرهاب، بل وأيضا في العملية السياسية.
ورأى مراقبون أن القصف الجوي الروسي في سورية طوال ثلاثة أسابيع كاملة أسفر عن تلك الزيارة السرية، التي تم الإعلان عنها عقب انتهائها بيوم واحد فقط. وشارك في اللقاء وزيرا الدفاع والخارجية الروسيان، بينما وصل الأسد من دمشق بمفرده على إحدى الطائرات الروسية. كما شارك في اللقاء أيضا مدير المخابرات الخارجية الروسية، فلاديمير فرادكوف، ومدير جهاز الأمن الفيدرالي نيكولاي باتروشيف.
وفي الوقت الذي تعالت فيه أبواق الإعلام السوري، وصقور دمشق للاحتفاء بهذه الزيارة "غير العادية، وغير الطبيعية"، معتبرين أنها صفعة لواشنطن وحلفائها، إلا أن مراقبين رأوا أن طبيعة الزيارة وتوقيتها يتحدثان عن أمور أخرى تماما. فهي تتزامن مع حدثين مهمين للغاية. الأول، توقيع موسكو وواشنطن مذكرة تفاهم حول ضمان سلامة طيران الجانبين لعدم وقوع حوادث أثناء التحليق والطلعات الجوية في الأجواء السورية، مع تشديد واشنطن على أنه لا يوجد أي تعاون عسكري مع روسيا، وأن الخلافات حول مصير الأسد لا تزال قائمة. والثاني هو المبادرة الأميركية لبحث سبل تسوية الأزمة السورية سياسيا، والجولات المكوكية التي يقوم بها وزير الخارجية الأميركي جون كيري في بعض الدول الأوروبية. هذه المبادرة طرحها كيري لتوحيد جهود "الولايات المتحدة والمملكة العربية السعودية وتركيا وروسيا" لإيجاد مداخل لتسوية سياسية ما للأزمة السورية.
مسارات سياسية
وأعربت تقارير إعلامية عن ثقتها بأن زيارة رئيس النظام السوري إلى موسكو، بحد ذاتها وبهذا الشكل، توضح أن هناك تفاهمات بين وجهات نظر كل من القيادتين الروسية والسورية. مما يجعل الحديث يدور عن إمكانية ظهور مسارات سياسية ومفاجآت مهمة خلال الفترة المقبلة.
من جانبه صرح وزير الدفاع الروسي سيرجي شويجو أنه لا يمكن لروسيا أن تسمح بتنامي الخطر الذي يمثله تنظيم داعش عليها وعلى حلفائها، ولذلك ستواصل دعم السلطات السورية في مواجهة التنظيم. وشدد على أن السلطات الحكومية في سورية، بفضل الدعم العسكري الروسي انتقلت من الدفاع إلى الهجوم، واستعادت جزءا من الأراضي التي سبق لتنظيم داعش أن استولى عليه. وقال "إننا نخطط لمواصلة تقديم المساعدة للسلطات في سورية، والعمل على توفير المقدمات لتسوية هذا النزاع".
مصالح
وكان رئيس الحكومة الروسية، ديمتري ميدفيديف، قال في وقت سابق إن روسيا "تدافع عن مصالحها القومية في سورية، لا عن أشخاص بعينهم، وبقاء بشار الأسد في السلطة ليس مسألة مبدئية بالنسبة لموسكو. إننا لا نقاتل لمصلحة قادة محددين، وإنما ندافع عن مصالحنا القومية، ومسألة الرئاسة السورية أمر يقرره الشعب السوري".
وقال ميدفيديف أيضا في تصريحاته للتلفزيون الروسي الحكومي إنه "لا بد من مناقشة القضايا السياسية بين روسيا والولايات المتحدة تحديدا، وبين جميع الدول المعنية بإحلال السلام في المنطقة، بما يخدم بروز سلطة طبيعية هناك. وليس من الأهمية من سيكون على رأس هذه السلطة. لا نريد أن يحكم تنظيم داعش في سورية، والسلطة هناك يجب أن تكون حضارية وشرعية. هذه هي الأشياء التي لا بد من بحثها".
كما ألمح مراقبون إلى أن هذه الزيارة يمكن أن تكون بالفعل بداية لحل سياسي، يرتكز إلى الاستغناء عن الأسد لاحقا وخلال مدة محددة، يمكن الاتفاق عليها في إطار اللقاءات التي يتم الترتيب لها بين واشنطن والرياض وأنقرة وموسكو. وذهبت إلى إمكانية أن تكون موسكو قد وصلت إلى مرحلة التمهيد لإبعاد الأسد، من أجل بدء تسويات سياسية تحظى بإجماع سوري. فيما يؤكد آخرون أنها "زيارة الوداع".
إلى ذلك، انتقد البيت الأبيض روسيا، لاستقبالها الرسمي الأسد، وقال المتحدث باسمه أريك شولتز للصحفيين على متن طائرة الرئيس الأميركي: "نعتبر الاستقبال الرسمي للأسد الذي استخدم أسلحة كيماوية ضد شعبه متعارضا مع الهدف المعلن من جانب الروس من أجل انتقال سياسي في سورية". تداعيات الزيارة

I'm holding my forecast at 30%, where it's been all along. I interpret the trip as a message to Iran that Russia is now the dominant power in Syria, and Assad's survival no longer depends on Iran. Now, Iran is the junior partner to Russia, and Putin calls the shots. When Assad calls for a comprehensive peace including all the ethnic and religious groups in Syria, we have to remember that he's from a minority himself. I think what he's doing is offering himself as an anti-ISIS rallying point. If you are a Christian, Druze, or Shiite, or even a Sunni who dreads rule by ISIS, Assad starts to look pretty good. I don't consider his statements an offer to step down, or for a "transition" (which the NYT called it, not Assad). It's an offer by Putin to combat ISIS, on the condition that Assad stays in power. I doubt if the Russia-Saudi Arabia-Turkey meeting will discuss replacing Assad. It will probably entail a proposal by Russia for all factions in Syria, and their sponsors, to unite against ISIS.  Assad didn't go to Moscow for a trivial reason, as many forecasters have observed. But he didn't go to discuss his own deposition, assassination or exile either. I don't think the Afghanistan precedent holds here. An important distinction is that there was an alternative in Afghanistan in 1979. For now, there is no apparent alternative in Syria. Here's an interesting story from 2012 that's germane to this thread: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/tensions-among-alawites-pose-new-challenge-for-assad/2012/10/17/e5e51af6-1881-11e2-a346-f24efc680b8d_story.html Note the detail that a potential rival groomed by Moscow was arrested. Certainly anyone who appears as a potential rival to Assad is taken out of the picture upon being recognized as a threat. Assad may wind up deposed or dead some time in the future, even with Moscow's complicity, but I consider this Moscow trip to be an indication of his resilience, not his imminent overthrow.

Adjust for developments. Regimes like Assad’s are tribal in nature. They have the trappings of western nation states, but power, wealth, and resources flow down from the top in a food chain of payments for loyalty to various sub-tribes. The glue that holds these regimes together is the confidence tribal leaders have in the stability of the food chain. Once that confidence is shaken, the will to continue as a united chain starts to disintegrate into every man for himself. At this point the will to fight on the ground fragments accordingly, a tipping point is reached, and the advantage goes to the other side - assuming no evidence exists that their food chain is not similarly compromised. You can look at Assad’s recent trip to Moscow two ways. The first is to imagine that a deal to remove Assad is underway, but to my mind, just that impression would be enough to deal a mortal blow to the food chain that is keeping the Syrian state together. More likely it seems to me, is that this was a show of very dramatic and visible superpower support for that food chain, increasing the likelihood of its survival. At the same time, no clear evidence suggests that the food chain on the other side has changed much.

Russia's support for Syria is a major vote of confidence from a growing militaristic and economic power in the region.  Russia's strategic move, creating a base in Syria is for the chief reason of keeping Assad in power.  The West does not have the political will to face off with Russia in an attempt to subvert Assad. Things to consider.... 18 months is a very long time. The long time frame allows for any number of significant developments to occur in the region as well as across the world, both directly related as well as indirectly. The increasing complexity and chaotic nature of the region coupled with the time frame allows for a greater probability of short tail events. Assad is young and by all accounts, healthy. Civil wars are not uncommon, and when they occur it can take years to resolve them. Significant outside intervention can lengthen civil wars and with them, regimes.  Civil wars that resolve against the status quo always result in the removal of the head of state, one way or another. In the context of a civil war, flight or assassination are not short tail events. Any number of setbacks can occur before Assad ceases to be “President” - removing the label is different than removing the man. News and opinion from the region should be considered suspect.

Assad is now supported by a major power whose government is determined to make his survival a test case of that power's ability to assert its influence in the Middle East. Were Assad to fall, Putin's prestige at home and Russia's influence abroad would both decline sharply. Putin and the Russian security establishment cannot permit such an outcome. To that end, they will use every tool at their disposal - from missiles to bombers to "volunteer" commandos, disinformation and lies, and worse.
Another reason that Assad will survive is that, even in the presence of a well-organized and well-supported insurgency,  regimes in the modern era typically hold up at least a decade before falling. Most insurgencies, including successful ones, take a generation to achieve their aims.  The Syrian insurgency is less than five years old. It is fragmented, poorly-supplied, and in want of a clear, charismatic, forceful leader. Expecting this haphazard crew to topple Assad, given the weight that Russia places on his survival , within the next 18 months is akin to expecting the Democratics to sweep the House races in the South in November 2016.

Russia's increasing involvement is aimed at shoring up al-Assad's rule, making it unlikely he would cease to be president.  The continued civil war in Syria keeps a wildcard on the table that could see him assassinated, but that too is unlikely.

There are two plausible scenarios that would lead to Assad leaving power: military defeat by a rebel group or alliance of groups; or a negotiated transfer of power to a successor acceptable to both the current government's supporters and to anti-Assad rebels, in exchange for a ceasefire. The former scenario seems very unlikely (~5%) given recent Russian intervention in Syria, which appears to indicate a resolve to keep Assad in power as a useful Middle Eastern ally. The latter scenario is also  rather unlikely (~5%), as a 'peace process' settlement would need to be acceptable to both anti-Assad and pro-Assad groupings, and it is difficult to see what form of compromise could do this. Therefore, I do not think there is any more than a 10% likelihood of Assad leaving power in the given timespan.

Outside interventions in civil wars tend to prolong those civil wars, despite the intentions of those intervening and regardless of intention. Assad will fall eventually, but Putin just bought him some time.

The main message Putin wanted to get across was that there would be serious consequences should the Gulf states include man-portable air defense systems in their plans for augmenting rebel support. Russia believes sending SA-22 surface-to-air missiles to Syria to provide air defense for Russian forces in country (never mind that the rebels lack air power) is fair, but "rebel-sponsors" putting surface-to-air missiles in their hands willing to shoot down Russian planes is not. This is the same message that the US had issued to the Saudis and other Gulf allies: Surface-to-air missiles are a "red line." Rival insurgents say that the Islamic State, also called ISIS or Daesh, is taking advantage. “Daesh has exploited the Russian airstrikes and the preoccupation of the Free Syrian Army in its battles in Hama, and advanced in Aleppo,” one rebel commander told Reuters. The Islamic State advance is threatening a strategic area north of Aleppo on the way to crossing points into Turkey that was to be part of a proposed ISIS-free buffer zone under a plan the United States announced over the summer with Turkey. U.S. forces have parachuted small arms ammunition to Syrian rebels in northern Syria, a U.S. military spokesman said Oct. 12, Reuters reported. The airdrop of supplies was part of a revamped U.S. strategy to help Syrian rebels battling Islamic State militants. Washington had shelved a program to train and equip "moderate" rebels opposed to President Bashar al Assad who would join the fight against the Islamic State. Only the Kurdish People's Protection Units have had success against the militant group while cooperating with the U.S.-led coalition, so to which units did the parachute drop go to? I have read (al-Monitor, Stratfor, Foreign Policy, al-Jazeera)  that during the Grand Prix events recently held in Sochi, Russia (of Winter Olympic fame) short sit-down meetings between Saudi Royalty and Putin representatives were confrontational.  What does this mean? The main message Putin wanted to get across was that there would be serious consequences should the Gulf states include man-portable air defense systems in their plans for augmenting rebel support. Russia believes sending SA-22 surface-to-air missiles to Syria to provide air defense for Russian forces in country (never mind that the rebels lack air power) is fair, but "rebel-sponsors" putting surface-to-air missiles in their hands willing to shoot down Russian planes is not. This is the same message that the US had issued to the Saudis and other Gulf allies: Surface-to-air missiles are a "red line." The United States learned this lesson the hard way during the Cold War and have expended a lot of time, money and energy already in trying to track down (e.g. Afghanistan, Libya). Whether the Saudis will continue to respect the "red line" on man-portable air defense systems, however, remains to be seen. There are already reports that the Saudis are sending an additional 500 TOW missiles to Syria in an effort to blunt the current Russian-led offensive. In other news, the US had agreed to bail our Iraqi budget deficits of $6-7 billion dollars. Funny, after Iraqi alliance with Russia, but part of the the geopolitical wrangling in the area, I guess.  And Israel struck southern Syria after rocket- attacks from that regions. Is an Israel intervention in the offing?  Unmitigating war does make strange bedfellows. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 12OCT15 Update: Stalled loyalist advance sputters to life, takes village. From "not since WWII" and "return to the Cold War," these are words from past conflicts and tensions trying to describe what is new, novel, unexpected, and will be settled on the battlegrounds of the future. I love these maps, because they clearing describe reality where little else can. 10OCT15 Update: Islamic State closes in on Syrian city of Aleppo Islamic State is now within 2 km (1.2 miles) of government-held territory on the northern edge of Aleppo, which has suffered widespread damage and disease during the civil war that erupted in the wake of protests against Assad. - Reuter, 09OCT15 Syria's military, backed by Russia, Iran and allied militias, has launched a major attack in Syria's west to recapture land lost to non-IS rebels near the heartland of Assad's minority Alawite sect. That area is vital to Assad's survival. Russian forces carried out airstrikes Oct. 10 across northern and western Syria in a continuation of their ongoing bombing campaign, Reuters reported. The northern airstrikes hit targets in northern Latakia and Hama province, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Strikes in the west were accompanied by loyalist ground assaults and targeted non-Islamic State rebel groups. The Islamic State registered significant gains on Friday in the area of northwestern Syria that Russian warplanes have been bombing, taking six villages near Aleppo and threatening to cut off an important route north to the Turkish border. Late in the day, there were reports that rebels had reasserted control in one village. The Kremlin has said its military had entered Syria to fight the Islamic State, but the Russian forces have concentrated much of their firepower on insurgent groups aligned against President Bashar al-Assad, including the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria, and relatively secular groups like the Free Syrian Army. Rival insurgents say that the Islamic State, also called ISIS or Daesh, is taking advantage. “Daesh has exploited the Russian airstrikes and the preoccupation of the Free Syrian Army in its battles in Hama, and advanced in Aleppo,” one rebel commander told Reuters. The Islamic State advance is threatening a strategic area north of Aleppo on the way to crossing points into Turkey that was to be part of a proposed ISIS-free buffer zone under a plan the United States announced over the summer with Turkey. That plan now seems to have stalled. => http://nyti.ms/1Lb0CIi

The operation is meant to reverse rebel gains made over the summer that threaten the coastal region vital to the government of President Bashar al Assad. According to reports, the offensive failed to make significant gains against the rebels. Let' stop right there. Mi Mu-24 helicopters to many of us in the west conjure up so many images! Hollywood ("Charlie Wilson's War"), Mujaheddin, the Afghani resistance to Soviet authority, the rise of both CIA involvement in that war supplying Stinger missiles and of our "ally" at the time, Osama bin Laden. We're now on to "loyalists" and "rebels", which reminds us of battlefields in Spain fought out as - in one analysis - the first salvos of of WWII. But history does not repeat itself. In that civil war (can we use that term in Syria, "civil war"? Perhaps not yet, but soon?) Here again Russia backs "loyalists", but is forced to more openly. Here again a rebel force takes shape. al-Assad, of course is no Spanish Republic, anymore than the rebels are Franco-inspired. But the scenario is playing out between the superpowers in a similar vein , as Russia tries out new militarily techniques and strategies similar to pre-WWII Germany flexing its military innovation. The United States will not cooperate militarily with Russia in Syria because the Kremlin's strategy is "tragically flawed," U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said Oct. 7, Reuters reported. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said on Oct. 8 that Turkey’s imports of Russian natural gas and Russia's construction of Turkey’s first nuclear power plant are at risk due to Russia’s bombing of Syria and recent violations of Turkish airspace, AFP reported.

I believe Russian (and Iranian) support had bought al-Assad SOME time.
These are the facts as I see it:
- Al-Assad's government control less than 15% of Syria.
- The Syrian economy and military are in bad shape (I don't think they're capable of recapturing more than 30 - 35% of the country even with Russian help).
- A healthy % of the Syrian population (news reports say a lot of draft-age men and even some of al-Assad supporters) continue to flee the turmoil. 
- Saudi Arabia (leading an alliance of Gulf states) has flat-out stated that al-Assad needs to go. 
- Putin and the Saudi defense minister apparently agree to common goals regarding Syria, but I don't think that'll change Saudi minds on al-Assad.
- RU is still fighting a war in UKR. Involvement in two military ventures (+ a weak economy) has to be a drain on the Russian treasury. How long can Putin commit?  
Affirming forecast.

It seems that the possibility is greater than I thought, although according to Der Spiegel, Assad is worried about the Iranians, not the Russians. I have thought all along that the intentions of Iran and Russia mean that their alliance may not survive success. Each wants control of Syria for its own reasons, and those reasons are essentially zero-sum. They cannot both get what they want in Syria. I find it difficult to believe that the Iranians would concede control of all or part of the coast to Russia in the event of victory. And I find it improbable that any joint Russian-Iranian condominium and shared military/naval facilities could last.

With the support of Russia the rebel groups in the west of Syria have already been crippled (despite claims they are hitting ISIS) with the aid of Russia the regime is unlikely fall to the rebels. The Russian government will not want to lose its ally in the region and is unlikely to let Assad fall. Neither Russia nor America is likely to let ISIS get to a point where they are toppling the government. 20 percent seems right to me as although I don think he will be deposed there is still a chance of assassination or him fleeing etc.
With both Iran and Russia doubling down to prop up Assad, he may not be going anywhere for quite a while.

Good news for those seeking the establishment of an independent Kurdistan: Russia allegedly is negotiating an alliance with leaders of the region of Syria controlled by the Kurds (Rojava). However, Turkey is a member of NATO and sees those attempting to create an independent Kurdistan as a serious threat, given the history of terrorism and civil war with Turkey's Kurds. Assuming this news is true and not just a cynical ruse to garner U.S. support, how would this Russian/Kurd alliance affect Assad? My guess is that beggars can't be choosers. If the price of saving Assad is to create the new nation of Kurdistan bordering Turkey, this most excellent way of discomfiting a NATO nation will be the price Assad must pay. In return, I expect Russia will protect Assad come whatever in order to show the dictators of the world that Russia is a reliable ally. This amounts to a real advantage in waging naval warfare in the Levant or Middle East for Russia. Intense Russian airstrikes accompanied a ground offensive by loyalist forces around Hama and nearby areas in Idlib province for the first time on Oct. 7, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, The Telegraph reported. The fighting, described as the most intense fighting in months, launched around the town of Morek that links Damascus to the northern hub of Aleppo. On Oct. 6, a pro-rebel media outlet reported that Russia had spent the past week establishing a base in southeastern Hama, with the presence of Russian forces expanding noticeably throughout the city. With the help of foreign backers, loyalists and rebels will launch two major advances that will shape the course of the Syrian conflict. The Fall of Two Campaigns - The first offensive stems from Russia and Iran's effort to stabilize Syrian President Bashar al Assad's forces and to restore their advantage on the battlefield. If successful, the effort could put the Syrian government in a much more favorable position at the bargaining table when it comes to discussing a possible negotiated settlement to the conflict. The offensive will target three areas: the northern Homs pocket, the al-Ghab plain and its surrounding mountains in northwest Hama, and the Kweiris air base. The successful eradication of rebel forces in the northern Homs pocket would eliminate a dangerous rebel position close to the critical cities of Homs and Hama while freeing up a large number of loyalist troops for operations elsewhere. Turkey, Jordan, Gulf Arab states and the United States are preparing to bolster the Syrian rebels with further supplies of weaponry and equipment. Most notably, the United States has backed a new push against the Islamic State in Syria that aims to secure the remaining Islamic State-occupied areas on the Syria-Turkey border while threatening the group's de facto capital, Raqqa. Washington insists that these plans have been in the works since before Russia's latest intervention in Syria, but it is clear that Moscow's activities will only provide additional impetus for the U.S.-backed rebel offensive.

Think large and reason well. These could be the watchwords for anyone trying to forecast Syria a year and a half into the future. Suspecting larger forces would array over 2 weeks ago I observed, "...the fresh involvement of Russia in arming and aiding the al-Assad regime underscores the key players actively pursuing their interests in the region. This will not be quiet and will not be quick." Boy-howdee! Let's review a few thing that have happen JUST OVER THIS PAST WEEKEND (yes, I'm shouting): (1) Under United Nations supervision, Hezbollah and the government of President Bashar al Assad reached a deal Sept. 24 with Syrian rebels on fighting in Idlib and Rif Dimashq provinces, The Daily Star reported. The agreement will be fulfilled within six months, before which the two sides will observe a local cease-fire. Under the deal, rebel forces will pull out of the city of Zabadani, which is near the Lebanese border in Rif Dimashq province. Rebels will also allow civilians to evacuate from Fuaa and Kafriyeh, two Shiite towns under siege by rebels in Idlib province in the northwest. Both sides will be allowed to remove their wounded from the areas beginning Sept. 25. (2) Iraqi military officials are engaged in intelligence and security cooperation with Russia, Iran, and Syria to counter the Islamic State, the Iraqi military's joint operations command said, Al Jazeera reported Sept. 27. The cooperation comes as Russia steps up its military involvement in Syria, while pressing for Damascus to be included in international efforts to fight the Islamic State. A military-diplomatic source in Moscow also said officers of the four countries would lead a Baghdad coordination center on a rotating basis, starting with Iraq. (3) Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has declared Sept. 28 a national holiday in Iraq and closed the Green Zone, a decision unnamed Iraqi military and intelligence sources say was motivated in anticipation of a possible coup attempt, Gulf Online reported. The prime minister received intelligence indicating that a coup would be led by officers loyal to former Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, the sources said. Al-Maliki and other senior Iraqi political figures, lawmakers and ministers have reportedly fled to southern Iraq. A lawmaker with al-Maliki’s Rule of Law coalition denied the reports, Al Sumaria reported. Brushing aside the question of whether the US diplomats were caught "off-guard" in Iraq (really, again?), the coalition that Russia is forging is not a surprising alliance of interests. Those interests have been at play in the region for most of the 21st Century. What is surprising is the speed and rapidity of Russian moves in the region, first militarily followed by diplomacy. If a forecaster views these events as independent of, say, the building storm and perhaps attempts at coup in Moldova, Nordstream/Southstream (Anystream?), or the now relative quietude settling over eastern Ukraine, it may appear as the al Assad regime has finally found its long-lost friend who has now come back to bank-roll its survival. Um, yeah. A larger view will see the position Russia, for very little relative commitment, has staked out in the Levant and beyond. In addition, one will notice the change in media attention, and activity on the battlefield. Away from ISIS terror and towards Russian military build-up and Syrian government build-up, and accord-building on a "final outcome in Syria". As an example, Russia, the United States, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Egypt will meet in October to discuss the Syrian conflict, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Mikhail Bogdanov said, RIA Novosti reported Sept. 28. Others could be invited to the talks, which will include four Syrian working groups and which will take place after the U.N. General Assembly. Of course, armed conflict has its own life. And while a little relative commitment today in aiding "an old ally and friend" may garner opportunities for greater political and diplomatic leverage over "superrivals", it may turn on a different point. Such moves by superpowers in close military proximity are historically these type turning points. Enough said. Oh yes, forecast up to 76%.

Right now it looks as if Asad will cease being president if he dies of natural causes or an assassin gets lucky.  There are several others scenarios for removing Asad but none looks likely before March 2017: 1) the Syrian government collapses as it's militarily defeated on the battlefield. How likely is this now? I don't know whether the Sunni jihadis have got the capability to defeat Asad's forces and storm a key city like Damascus. A feature of Arab civil wars is that they tend towards stalemate and de facto political division rather than outright victory for one side or the other. 2) An internal coup - this would almost certainly precipitate the government's collapse so government supporters don't look to have much choice but to hang together.  3) Asad voluntarily leaving as a result of an international peace agreement. Even Philip Hammond's given up on this one. There's some curveballs: Sunni mass graves, chemical weapons, a Turkish invasion of the Kurdish fiefdoms. It's worth bearing in mind how things have switched from two years ago when David Cameron wanted to take Asad's forces out in a bombing campaign. Now we're doing a 180 with Cameron wanting to bomb the people we were going to intervene to protect in 2013. It's difficult to keep up.

COMMENT:  I note in "More Info" on this question that it says "In the event that Assad reportedly disappears or flees the capital. . ."  and that this question includes the words "President" and "Syria" which are not defined.  What if Assad, while still claiming to be the President of Syria, is forced to leave Damascus and retreat to a stronghold in/around Latakia, and we or the Russians, or Iranians, or Saudis start to work with someone else in Damascus?  Or, what if the role/powers of the president of Syria are dramatically changed and Assad is allowed to keep this title but stripped of his power?    I consider both of those scenarios distinctly possible--75%--but how would the judges consider them?  Would the question resolve as "Yes"  or "No" if either of them occurred? I would argue that this question should resolve as "Yes" if
- Assad's powers are permanently significantly reduced by international action or by internal legislation or some sort of coup. . . that what matters is not al-Assad's title, but his power.
- Assad has to leave Damascus and sets up his seat of government elsewhere. . . that what matters is who leads the government from Damascus
- Syria is effectively partitioned and someone else is recognized internationally as the leader of that part of Syria which includes Damascus . . . that no matter what anyone calls it, "Syria" is that nation that includes Damascus as its capital and center of government.

March 2017 is too soon. A war of attrition can last a very long time. Battlefield and territorial losses indicate that Assad is losing the war, but it will take a very long time for him to be defeated/removed from power (estimated 3-6 years). A new interventionist president, whether it is Clinton, Bush, or Trump could be a game-changer. But an escalation on the part of the US won't happen until after Obama leaves and the question closes. Reasons why Assad will stay in power until March 2017: Assad has reinforcements from Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah, with possibly a lot more on the way. He also has control of the population centers, which gives him access to potential recruits. He has the advantage in air power, which is a force multiplier. He could still improve his situation by shifting away from his "army in all corners" strategy. Finally, the rebels might have trouble if the Syrian army hunkers down in a defensive posture. Starting out cautiously because I haven't done the analytical work yet. Sources: "The Crisis of the Assad Regime" by Jeffrey White, The Washington Institute for Near East Policy: http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-crisis-of-the-assad-regime

Russian support continues to escalate. While this is to Assad's advantage, this would not be happening unless the situation is dire. Comparison class: Supposing that Putin has no intention of replacing Assad, consider a counterfactual scenario from the U.S. Civil War. History records that the Confederacy tried to obtain European allies, as did the North. However, the Confederacy was unable to even establish diplomatic relations with any potential ally. On the other side, Russia actively supported the North by sending its warships to Union ports on both the Atlantic and Pacific in order to deter potential meddling by other nations on the side of the Confederacy. However, that was as far as it went. Now consider a counterfactual scenario: what if Lincoln and Congress had arranged for Russia to build military bases and ports and bring in its military personnel? The only way that would have happened would have been as a dire last resort. Another comparison class: Vietnam, 1963 until Nixon's Vietnamization strategy, followed soon by defeat. One may argue that once the U.S. began building bases and pouring weapons and soldiers into that civil war, it was clear that the situation was desperate, almost hopeless. The U.S. deposed Diem but it wasn't enough, ultimately. On the other hand: In general, any question that asks, "Will event A happen" is more likely to have less than 50% likelihood. So I've been way out in Brier punishment land with a 90% Assad is doomed prediction. So I'm scaling back to 85%.

Let's review a few thing that have happen JUST OVER THIS PAST WEEKEND (yes, I'm shouting): (1) Under United Nations supervision, Hezbollah and the government of President Bashar al Assad reached a deal Sept. 24 with Syrian rebels on fighting in Idlib and Rif Dimashq provinces, The Daily Star reported. The agreement will be fulfilled within six months, before which the two sides will observe a local cease-fire. Under the deal, rebel forces will pull out of the city of Zabadani, which is near the Lebanese border in Rif Dimashq province. Rebels will also allow civilians to evacuate from Fuaa and Kafriyeh, two Shiite towns under siege by rebels in Idlib province in the northwest. Both sides will be allowed to remove their wounded from the areas beginning Sept. 25. (2) Iraqi military officials are engaged in intelligence and security cooperation with Russia, Iran, and Syria to counter the Islamic State, the Iraqi military's joint operations command said, Al Jazeera reported Sept. 27. The cooperation comes as Russia steps up its military involvement in Syria, while pressing for Damascus to be included in international efforts to fight the Islamic State. A military-diplomatic source in Moscow also said officers of the four countries would lead a Baghdad coordination center on a rotating basis, starting with Iraq. (3) Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has declared Sept. 28 a national holiday in Iraq and closed the Green Zone, a decision unnamed Iraqi military and intelligence sources say was motivated in anticipation of a possible coup attempt, Gulf Online reported. The prime minister received intelligence indicating that a coup would be led by officers loyal to former Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, the sources said. Al-Maliki and other senior Iraqi political figures, lawmakers and ministers have reportedly fled to southern Iraq. A lawmaker with al-Maliki’s Rule of Law coalition denied the reports, Al Sumaria reported. Brushing aside the question of whether the US diplomats were caught "off-guard" in Iraq (really, again?), the coalition that Russia is forging is not a surprising alliance of interests.  Those interests have been at play in the region for most of the 21st Century.  What is surprising is the speed and rapidity of Russian moves in the region, first militarily followed by diplomacy. If a forecaster views these events as independent of, say, the building storm and perhaps attempts at coup in Moldova, Nordstream/Southstream (Anystream?), or the now relative quietude settling over eastern Ukraine, it may appear as the al Assad regime has finally found its long-lost friend who has now come back to bank-roll its survival.  Um, yeah.  A larger view will see the position Russia, for very little relative commitment, has staked out in the Levant and beyond. In addition, one will notice the change in media attention, and activity on the battlefield.  Away from ISIS terror and towards Russian military build-up and Syrian government build-up, and accord-building on a "final outcome in Syria".   As an example, Russia, the United States, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Egypt will meet in October to discuss the Syrian conflict, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Mikhail Bogdanov said, RIA Novosti reported Sept. 28. Others could be invited to the talks, which will include four Syrian working groups and which will take place after the U.N. General Assembly. Of course, armed conflict has its own life.  And while a little relative commitment today in aiding "an old ally and friend" may garner opportunities for greater political and diplomatic leverage over "superrivals", it may turn on a different point. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/05/world/middleeast/russian-moves-in-syria-pose-concerns-for-us.html?emc=edit_th_20150905&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 9/5/15 Russia has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps that may signal that Putin is planning to vastly expand his military support for al-Assad of Syria. The Russian moves include the recent transport of prefabricated housing units for as many as 1,000 advisers or other military personnel  to a Syrian airfield serving Latakia, the delivery of a portable air traffic control station there, and  military overflight requests with neighboring countries through September. There is no indication that Russia intends to deploy significant numbers of ground forces, but the housing would enable Russia to use the airfield as a major hub for ferrying in military supplies for the Syrian government, or possibly as a launching pad for Russian airstrikes in support of Mr. Assad’s forces. Putin dismissed news reports that Russia had sent ground troops to fight in Syria as “premature.”  “We are looking at various options, but so far what you are talking about is not on the agenda,” he said. American intelligence analysts are also looking at ship loadings in Russia to determine what might be bound for Syria, and one official speculated that the Russian deployment might eventually grow to 2,000 to 3,000 personnel.  “There was no confirmation that large numbers of Russian soldiers, aircraft or heavy weapons had yet arrived.   If these reports are borne out, it would represent a very serious shift in the trajectory of the Syria conflict and call into question any Russian commitment to a peaceful settlement," say some.  But outlining his ideas on a potential diplomatic solution, Mr. Putin suggested that it be carried out in parallel with the fight against extremists and that Mr. Assad should play a role in the political process.  If Mr. Putin’s intention is to support not just the Syrian government but also Mr. Assad, that could undercut Mr. Kerry’s contention that the Syrian president needs to leave power as part of any political solution to the conflict.  And if Russian pilots carried out airstrikes, administration officials say, the choice of targets might further aggravate the growing chaos, if Russia targets rebel groups that are opposed to Mr. Assad. Another possibility is that Russia is taking these steps to secure its own interests in the event that the Assad government collapses, reaches a power-sharing agreement with the opposition or is replaced. By expanding its military influence in Syria, Russia might be in a stronger position to shape the political outcome as the Assad government’s military position weakens by encouraging it to share power with opposition members Moscow supports. A former DIA officer who now studies Syria for a think tank, said “All this tells me is that the Russians are not backing away from the Assad regime,” he said.

http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-russia-syria-20150905-story.html U.S. officials  fear Moscow will help Assad's forces attack the government's opponents, some of whom the U.S. backs. The increased Russian involvement could extend Assad's hold on power. Until now, the Russian government has provided the Assad government financial support, intelligence information, weapons and spare parts for its Russian-made military equipment, but had not sent troops to Syria. Images of Russian-built warplanes and reconnaissance drones have appeared on social media accounts belonging to Syrian opposition fighters.  "Any military support to the Assad regime for any purpose, whether it's in the form of military personnel, aircraft supplies, weapons or funding, is both destabilizing and counterproductive," White House spokesman said. The Syrian government is one of Russia's only allies in the region. Russia's sole military installation outside the borders of the former Soviet Union is a Cold War-era naval base in the Syrian city of Tartus. The base is some 35 miles south of Bassel al Assad International Airport, where the new Russian staging area is apparently being built. With the buildup, the Russians could be looking to increase their ability to resupply Assad's forces and bolster his tenuous hold on power. Assad's army has lost large numbers of soldiers and weapons amid rebel advances. The Russians also could help guard the Alawite home territory to ensure that Assad has a secure escape route and refuge if he loses control of the capital. While Putin routinely rejects Western demands that Assad step down and make way for peace and a new government of national unity, the Kremlin leader has lately intimated that his support for the embattled Syrian leader may have its limits.
Erdogan met with Putin in June and told journalists that he sensed a change in the Russian leader's previously unfettered backing of Assad. "He is no longer of the opinion that Russia will support Assad to the end. I believe he can give up Assad," Erdogan said. "It's pretty obvious that all the Russian logistics preparation is to do something significant in support of Assad," said a military analyst at the Institute for the Study of War, The Obama administration has said it would welcome Russia's involvement to help defeat Islamic State. So far Russia has not joined the campaign against the militants and has avoided direct involvement in the fight.  Asked Friday about that possibility, Putin brushed it aside. "We are already providing Syria with quite strong support in terms of equipment, training of military servicemen and weapons," he said. Since the Syrian civil war began in 2011, a steady stream of Russian weapons and resupply shipments have entered Syria to help Assad's forces.  But in recent weeks, reports show that assistance escalating. In August, news footage from Syria showed updated versions of Russian-made BTR-82A fighting vehicles with Russian military markings that hadn't been seen before in the country. A video clip from the conflict also appeared to show orders being given in Russian to a tank operator. Also last month, a website that tracks ships moving through the strait between the Black Sea and the Mediterranean published photos of a Russian landing ship that appeared to be carrying several armored vehicles under camouflage netting and four military transport trucks. "Russia is one of Syria's most important allies and has supplied military and political support to the Assad regime since the beginning of this crisis," a U.S. intelligence official said. "Whether stories of increased Russian assistance are wishful thinking or real support, they do highlight the increasing desperation of the Assad regime."

Saudi Arabia, Turkey and the US demand Assad be removed. 
Putin is resisting this.
1) he doesn’t be seen as betraying an ally
2) he can’t allow himself to comply with a “regime change” doctrine that could eventually be used against him in a future coup.  3) he cannot simply hand Washington an easy victory on a matter of this magnitude  So, in June, Putin met with the heads of opposition groups and high-ranking officials from Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Syria, Iraq and Iran.  The goal was to implement the so-called Geneva communiqué that was ratified in June 30, 2012, which does not resolve the central issue, which is: “Does Assad stay or go?”   Putin really wants to “preserve government institutions, including the Syrian army” to avoid another Iraq-type nightmare scenario.What he doesn’t want, is to create a power-vacuum that leads to another failed, balkanized hellhole that serves as a breeding ground for terrorists that will eventually come knocking on Moscow’s door.  The whole idea of a “transitional governing body” and “free and fair multi-party elections” gives Putin a way to back away from Assad without looking like he’s throwing him under the bus.

Predictions of Assad's demise have been bouncing around for a couple of years now. None have come true yet. Couple factors worth considering: 

(1) The chance Assad will be killed by rebels is fairly small. Though rebels have managed to pick off a couple of high level generals over the past four years, Assad's security has held up thus far. 
(2) A military coup is possible, but Syria's Alawite community is fairly tightly bound to Assad. 
(3) All attempts to negotiate a settlement leading to Assad's peaceful departure have failed thus far. Momentum would likely have to turn strongly against Assad for him to consider such an option. 
(4) It is also unlikely that Assad will flee, as it would expose him to prosecution for war crimes, though a couple of countries have hinted at offering him protection (Iran, Russia, etc).
(5) Natural death or mental incapacitation is also unlikely, as Assad is only 49 years old and he isn't reported to be suffering from any type of serious medical conditions.  
(6) As this piece from the WP points out (http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/10/23/political-science-says-syrias-civil-war-will-probably-last-at-least-another-decade/), the average civil war lasts over 10-years. We are only 4-years into the Syrian one. It would be relatively abnormal for the war to come to a quick close in the near future.  
(7) Most external powers are more focused on ISIS than Assad at the moment. As ISIS the most organized and well equipped of Assad's challengers, this increases his odds of survival.
More entities want Assad gone than to stay. This includes ISIS and the US. There isn't a stable dictatorship and at this point there doesn't appear to be any political solutions on the table.
Syria is a distaster, and Bashar al-Assads leadership is much of the reason. 2017 is a long way off. At this point, I give better than even odds he won't last that long.
